Due to its straightforward synthesis and high electrochemical performance, the Co3O4/CNT nanocomposites demonstrate substantial potential as anode materials for sodium-ion batteries.

We have developed an advanced sodium-based dual-ion battery (Na-DIB) by integrating the benefits of dual-ion batteries (DIBs) and sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). This system utilizes a PTCDA organic anode and an ionic liquid (IL) electrolyte, resulting in a specific discharge capacity of 177 mAh g-1 at 0.5C and exceptional capacity retention of over 100% at 2C after 200 cycles. Remarkably, at an ultrahigh rate of 20C, the battery retains a substantial capacity of 60 mAh g-1 with a coulombic efficiency (CE) near 100 and retains 94% of its capacity after 1000 cycles. Additionally, the system's self-discharge has been determined to be extraordinarily low at 0.18% h-1. Hence, this research introduces an impressive Na-DIB system, offering potential for large-scale use.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are emerging as promising candidates for grid-scale energy storage systems, necessitating resilience to extreme weather. However, SIBs capable of operating over a broad temperature range are seldom documented. In this study, we introduce a wide-temperature SIB featuring a carbon-coated Na4Fe3(PO4)2P2O7 (NFPP@C) cathode, a Bismuth (Bi) anode, and a diglyme-based electrolyte. We show that the Bi anode can directly store solvated Na+ through an alloying reaction, bypassing the de-solvent step. Additionally, the NFPP@C cathode maintains a high Na+ diffusion coefficient at low temperatures. Consequently, the Bi//NFPP@C battery demonstrates excellent low-temperature performance; it retains 70.19% of its room-temperature capacity even at -70 °C. Moreover, due to the electrolyte's high boiling point, this battery also operates effectively at temperatures as high as 100 °C. These promising results may guide further development of wide-temperature SIBs.

Ultrafine niobium oxide nanocrystals/reduced graphene oxide (Nb2O5 NCs/rGO) has been identified as a promising anode material for sodium ion batteries, offering excellent rate performance and cycle durability. The Nb2O5 NCs/rGO was produced through the controlled hydrolysis of niobium ethoxide, followed by thermal treatment at 450 °C in a flowing forming gas environment. Transmission electron microscopy revealed that the Nb2O5 NCs, averaging 3 nm in size, were evenly distributed on rGO sheets, with voids apparent between the nanocrystals. The structure of ultrafine Nb2O5 NCs anchored on a highly conductive rGO network enhances charge transfer, mitigates volume changes during the sodiation/desodiation cycle, and offers increased active surface area for sodium ion storage, contributing to outstanding rate and cycling capabilities. Ex situ XPS analysis indicated that the sodium ion storage mechanism in Nb2O5 might involve a Nb(5+)/Nb(4+) redox reaction, with the ultrafine Nb2O5 NCs supplying more surface area to facilitate this redox process.

This study demonstrates, for the first time, the electrochemical activity of MnO2 as a conversion anode in sodium-ion batteries (NIBs). Space-confined ultrafine (UF)-MnO2, synthesized via a porous silicon dioxide templated hydrothermal procedure and possessing an average crystal size of 4 nm, shows a significant reversible sodiation capacity of 567 mA h g(-1). This is in stark contrast to the minimal activity seen in larger (14 nm) MnO2 nanocrystallite aggregates. The vastly improved sodiation activity of UF-MnO2 is due to its significantly reduced crystal size, which aids Na ion diffusion, and the high surface energy resulting from extensive heterogeneous interfacial bonding with the encasing SiO2. The UF-MnO2 anode also presents outstanding rate and cycle performance, maintaining over 70% capacity after 500 cycles. In operando X-ray absorption near-edge structure analysis using synchrotron reveals hybrid charge-storage mechanisms, involving a conversion reaction between Mn(III) and Mn(II) oxides, Mn(III)-O1.5 + Na(+) + e(-) ↔ 1/2Na2O + Mn(II)-O, along with non-Mn-centered redox reactions. This discovery proposes a novel approach to "activate" potential electrochemical electrode materials that are inactive in bulk form.

Contemporary lithium-ion batteries encounter issues related to sustainability, cost, and the availability of natural resources used in their construction. Sodium presents a promising alternative in energy storage by providing adequate volumetric energy density. In the development of sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), hard carbon is preferred for the anode instead of graphite, due to its required microdomain structure for storing sodium ions. Coal char offers an economical and feasible option as a hard carbon source. Utilizing coal char in SIBs also opens a valuable, alternative use for the plentiful char derived from coal.

This study explores flash pyrolysis as an innovative method for synthesizing coal char for SIB anodes, utilizing a local bituminous coal from Utah. Flash pyrolysis involves heating char in a drop-tube furnace at 1000 °C per second, contrasting the traditional, slower pyrolysis method that heats at 20 °C per minute. Analysis reveals that flash pyrolyzed (FP) char exhibits a significantly different surface structure than slow pyrolyzed (SP) char, featuring larger d-spacing (FP: 0.379 nm, SP: 0.364 nm) and smaller closed micropore diameter (FP: 1.52 nm, SP: 1.91 nm), as evidenced by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) data.

The SIB performance of FP versus SP char is assessed and contrasted in ether-based and ester-based electrolytes. FP char shows superior performance as a SIB anode compared to SP char across both electrolyte types. Additionally, both kinds of char anodes display higher reversible capacity and improved initial coulombic efficiencies (ICE) when used with an ether-based rather than an ester-based electrolyte. The FP char combined with an ether-based electrolyte achieves a 10th cycle reversible capacity of 109.4 mAh/g, while the SP char with an ester-based electrolyte only reaches 72.5 mAh/g, both cycled at 50 mA/g (sodium metal half-cells). FP ether cells also achieve a higher initial coulombic efficiency of 64%, compared to the 52% ICE of SP ester cells. The improved electrochemical performance of FP cells is attributed to structural differences induced by the rapid heating rate. The enhanced performance in ether-based cells may result from the formation of a thinner solid-electrolyte interphase and/or better sodiation facilitated by an ether-based electrolyte.

Sodium ion batteries (SIBs) are gaining renewed interest as an alternative to lithium ion batteries, mainly due to the affordability, plentiful availability of sodium, and similar storage mechanisms. VS4 has surfaced as an effective anode material for these batteries because of its cost-effectiveness and its distinct linear chain structure, which provides potential sites for sodium storage. In this study, we introduce the growth of VS4 on reduced graphene oxide (rGO), making it a novel anode for SIBs. This VS4/rGO anode demonstrates impressive performance, delivering a reversible capacity of 362 mAh g(-1) at a current rate of 100 mA g(-1), along with commendable rate performance. We examine the sodium storage characteristics of the VS4/rGO, revealing that, unlike most transition metal sulfides, the composite undergoes a three-phase separation during sodiation (transformation from VS4 to metallic V and Na2S, followed by electrochemical behavior similar to Na-S systems). This study establishes the VS4/rGO composite as a viable material for rechargeable SIBs.

The development of sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) with inherent safety and extended lifespan is critical for large-scale energy storage needs. Currently, most SIBs display limited cycling durability and safety concerns. In this study, we introduce an all-phosphate sodium-ion battery (AP-SIB) composed of a Na3V2(PO4)3 cathode, NaTi2(PO4)3 anode, and nonflammable trimethyl phosphate (TMP) electrolyte. The AP-SIB achieves superior safety, high rate capability, and extremely long cycle life, along with zero-strain properties, attributed to the opposite volume changes of the phosphate-based cathode and anode during charging and discharging. This creates a safer, cycle-durable Na-ion technology suitable for electric storage applications.

Designing suitable anode materials poses a significant challenge in advancing sodium ion batteries. Alloy anodes offer high gravimetric and volumetric capacities but experience short cycle life due to continuous and cumulative pulverization caused by substantial volume changes during cycling. In this study, we use pure Sn, an irreversible conversion reaction with an alloy reaction (SnO), and a reversible conversion reaction with an alloy reaction (Sn4P3) to illustrate that the pulverization and aggregation of the alloy anode can be partially reversed and halted during charge/discharge cycles through a reversible conversion reaction paired with an alloy reaction. Among the three Sn-based anodes, cycling stability improves in the order of Sn4P3 > SnO > Sn. The superior performance of Sn4P3 stems from the reversible reaction Sn4P3 + 9Na ↔ 4Sn + 3Na3P, which repairs cracks, damage, and Sn particle aggregation resulting from the alloying of 4Sn + 15Na ↔ Na15Sn4 during cycling, thereby preventing pulverization. This repair mechanism mimics natural self-healing, where damage is naturally repaired. Therefore, this concept can be referred to as self-healing, and the anode can be termed a self-healing anode. Introducing self-healing strategies in designing electrode architecture is innovative and highly desirable, as it enhances cycle life and offers a broadly applicable approach to developing stable electrode materials.

Potassium-ion batteries (PIBs) are gaining attention as alternative options to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) because potassium is both abundant and inexpensive. Our study explores a new anode material for PIBs: a Sn4P3/C composite. This electrode achieved a reversible capacity of 384.8 mA h g-1 at 50 mA g-1 and demonstrated a strong rate capability of 221.9 mA h g-1 at a higher current density of 1 A g-1, surpassing all previously reported anode materials for PIBs in terms of electrochemical performance. Additionally, the Sn4P3/C electrode exhibited a discharge potential plateau at 0.1 V for PIBs, which is slightly higher than the 0.01 V seen in sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) and safely above the metal plating potential. This characteristic reduces dendrite formation during cycling, making Sn4P3 a secure anode option, particularly beneficial for large-scale energy applications requiring substantial amounts of electrode material. We also suggest a potential reaction mechanism for the Sn4P3/C composite when used as a PIB anode. Our findings could usher in new advancements in alloy-based anodes that offer high capacity and extended cycle life for PIBs.

Single-layered MoS2 is an excellent anode material for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), and potassium-ion batteries (PIBs) due to its high capacity and uniform ion transport pathways. Nevertheless, its applications are restricted by low inherent conductivity and a tendency to agglomerate. This study introduces a charge-driven interlayer expansion approach where Co2+ substitutes Mo4+ as a dopant, giving MoS2 layers negative charges that cause electrostatic repulsion. This, along with the incorporation of gaseous groups, facilitates interlayer expansion by overcoming the van der Waals forces and achieving single-layered MoS2 that is evenly dispersed into a carbon matrix derived from carbonaceous gaseous groups under high vapor pressure. Co atom doping increases the intrinsic conductivity of the single-layered MoS2. The carbon matrix helps to prevent agglomeration. During the conversion reaction, doped Co atoms can transform into ultrasmall Co nanoparticles, which enhances spin-polarized surface capacitance, thereby significantly improving ion transport and storage. As a result, the developed material demonstrates excellent Li/Na/K-ion storage capabilities, outperforming previously reported MoS2-based anodes. This charge-driven interlayer expansion strategy offers a new approach for synthesizing single-layered MoS2, demonstrating significant potential for energy storage solutions.

Carbon-coated TiO2 microsphere electrodes with high power and long lifespan were produced via a hydrothermal method for use in sodium ion batteries, and their electrochemical performance was assessed based on varying carbon content. The introduction of a carbon coating, by adding sucrose, effectively inhibited the growth of TiO2 primary crystallites during calcination. The electrode with a 20 wt % sucrose carbon coating demonstrated outstanding cycle stability, maintaining 100% capacity over 50 cycles, and exhibited exceptional rate capability up to 30 C at room temperature. This electrode achieved a high discharge capacity of 155 mAh g(composite)(-1) at 0.1 C, 149 mAh g(composite)(-1) at 1 C, and 82.7 mAh g(composite)(-1) at a 10 C rate.

A three-dimensional spider-web architecture composed of Na2Ti3O7 nanotubes is produced via a hydrothermal synthesis method. This self-similar network demonstrates outstanding performance as an anode for sodium ion batteries operating at room temperature, notably without the use of any additives such as binders or conducting agents, for the first time.

Despite the dominance of lithium-ion battery (LIB) technology over the years, the rising demand and escalating costs of lithium resources necessitate the swift advancement of alternative energy storage solutions. Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), offering a cost-effective alternative with comparable electrochemical reaction properties, have garnered the interest of researchers. However, significant challenges remain due to sodium ions' larger ionic radius, leading to lower reversible capacity and reduced lifespan. Enhancing anode materials has emerged as a viable solution to these issues. This paper reviews the most recent research on potential anodes for SIBs and explores future prospects in this area.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are viable for extensive energy storage applications but face limitations in power density due to slow Na+ diffusion in cathode and anode materials. In this study, the authors present an ultrahigh power SIB prototype featuring a high-rate Na3V2(PO4)3 (NVP) cathode, a graphite-type mesocarbon microbeads (MCMB) anode, and a Na+-diglyme electrolyte. The findings show that the overpotential of the NVP cathode follows Ohmic behavior. As a result, the NVP@C@carbon nanotubes (CNTs) cathode, with its highly conductive CNTs network, exhibits significant electronic conductivity, which lowers overpotential and charge transfer resistance, achieving extraordinary rate capability exceeding 1000C. For the MCMB anode, the initial pseudocapacitive-dominated [Na-diglyme]+ co-intercalation step is followed by rapid ion diffusion facilitated by the expanded graphite layers. This efficient (de)intercalation process is well-aligned between the cathode and anode. Consequently, the MCMB|1 m NaPF6 in diglyme|NVP@C@CNTs full-cell SIB provides an energy density of 88 Wh kg−1 at a high power density of approximately 10 kW kg−1. Even at an ultrahigh power density of 23 kW kg−1, it achieves an energy density of 58 Wh kg−1. These promising full-cell results are expected to advance the development of high-power SIBs for large-scale applications in the future.

The behavior at the anode/electrolyte interface, and thus the overall performance of sodium-ion batteries, is influenced by a complex interplay of processes occurring throughout the electrochemical cell across a diverse range of size and time scales. Single-scale investigations may offer partial insights, failing to fully capture this intricate and interconnected behavior. Comprehensive multiscale studies are required to comprehend these processes. This perspectives article introduces several analytical and theoretical techniques, illustrating how they can be combined to achieve a thorough understanding of sodium-ion battery (SIB) performance over its lifespan, with a particular focus on hard carbon anode interfaces. These methods address various length and time scales, from micro to nano, from the cell level to atomic structures, and encompass a wide array of physical and (electro)chemical properties. Specifically, the use of mass spectrometric, microscopic, spectroscopic, electrochemical, thermodynamic, and physical methods to gather necessary information about battery behavior is explored. The article discusses how these methods can be integrated to clarify multiscale phenomena at the anode interface and develop a comprehensive understanding of their significance to the overall function of sodium-ion batteries.

Creating 3D graphene/metal composites characterized by ultrasmall metal sizes and strong metal-graphene interfacial interactions for energy storage remains challenging and infrequently documented. This study introduces a simple top-down approach to synthesize 3D N-doped porous graphene networks with SnSb nanocrystals for sodium ion battery anodes. These networks consist of interconnected N-graphene boxes with embedded ultrasmall SnSb nanocrystals. The design features complete plane-to-plane contact, forming an extensive interface between N-graphene and SnSb nanocrystals, which significantly boosts electron conductivity and structural integrity. It also provides excess interfacial sodium storage, resulting in greatly improved sodium storage capacity and stability at high rates, as supported by experimental results and first-principles simulations. Additionally, this top-down method opens new avenues for the cost-effective, high-yield production of 3D graphene/metal composites for energy-related and other applications.

We present a novel sodium-ion battery comprising a NaFePO₄ cathode paired with a nanocomposite tin-carbon (Sn-C) sodium-alloying anode. The NaFePO₄ cathode is produced via Li-Na conversion of a LiFePO₄ cathode within the complete cell, utilizing the Sn-C anode and a sodium-ion electrolyte. The findings demonstrate that this distinct strategy can effectively and efficiently transform LiFePO₄ into NaFePO₄ in a sodium-ion battery that operates at 3 V. It achieves a maximum reversible capacity of 150 mAh g⁻¹, alongside high reversibility and impressive rate capability.

Crystalline Covalent Organic Frameworks (COFs) feature structured nano-channels that can be supplemented with redox-active groups, allowing them to function as anodes in metal ion batteries like lithium-ion (LIB) and sodium-ion batteries (SIB). Despite sodium's greater natural abundance favoring its use over lithium, the difficulty in incorporating larger sodium ions into the commercial graphite anodes, which are used in LIBs due to unfavorable energy conditions, limits their compatibility. Additionally, the slow movement of sodium ions within electrodes impedes rapid sodiation in SIB. Enhancing the electronic driving force at the electrodes through chemical adjustment may address this issue. We introduce anodes for SIB developed using three structurally similar COFs, which maintain consistent Highest Occupied Molecular Orbitals (HOMO) levels but differ in the energy levels of their Lowest Unoccupied Molecular Orbitals (LUMO). This LUMO variability is intentionally achieved by incorporating electron-deficient groups (phenyl, tetrazine, and bispyridine-tetrazine) into the COFs' frameworks. As the cell potential decreases, electrons populate the anti-bonding LUMO, thereby enhancing these electron-rich LUMO levels to effectively attract otherwise slow-moving sodium ions from the electrolyte. Additionally, the COF's inherent porosity supports the accommodation and movement of Na+ ions. These COF-based cells achieve significant specific capacity (energy density) and rate performance (fast charging-discharging), a challenging feat for the larger Na+ ions compared to Li+. Notably, the COF with bispyridine-tetrazine, having the lowest LUMO energy, demonstrates a specific capacity of 340 mA h g-1 at a current density of 1 A g-1 and 128 mA h g-1 at 15 A g-1. Increasing the current density from 0.1 to 1 A g-1 results in just a 24% reduction, marking it as the most stable performance among the leading COF-derived Na-ion battery anodes.

Symmetric sodium-ion batteries offer advantages such as low cost, ease of manufacture, and simple recycling, making them ideal for large-scale stationary energy storage. In this study, we introduce a symmetric sodium-ion battery utilizing dual-electron reactions with the NASICON-structured Na3MnTi(PO4)3 material. The Na3MnTi(PO4)3 electrode provides a stable capacity of up to 160 mAh g-1 and a coulombic efficiency of 97% at 0.1 C, enabled by Ti3+/4+, Mn2+/3+, and Mn3+/4+ redox reactions. This represents the first exploration of a symmetric sodium-ion full-cell using Na3MnTi(PO4)3 as both the cathode and anode within an organic electrolyte, showcasing excellent reversibility and cycling performance with voltage plateaus at approximately 1.4 V and 1.9 V. The full-cell achieves a reversible capacity of 75 mAh g-1 at 0.1 C and an energy density of 52 Wh kg-1. Moreover, ex-situ XRD analysis and first-principle calculations are used to study the sodiation mechanism and structural changes. This research proposes a viable approach for enhancing the energy density of symmetric sodium-ion batteries.

To develop a high-performance anode for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), binary zinc phosphides (ZnP2 and Zn3P2) were produced using a straightforward solid-state heat treatment method, and their sodium storage properties were analyzed. ZnP2 demonstrated superior sodium reactivity compared to Zn3P2. Consequently, a carbon-modified ZnP2-based composite (ZnP2-C) was created to enhance electrochemical performance. To explore the electrochemical reaction mechanism of ZnP2-C during sodiation/desodiation, several ex-situ analytical techniques were used. During sodiation, ZnP2 in the composite converted into NaZn13 and Na3P phases, showing a one-step conversion reaction. In contrast, during desodiation, Zn and P in NaZn13 and Na3P fully recombined to form the original ZnP2 phase. Due to this one-step conversion/recombination process of ZnP2 in the composite during cycling, ZnP2-C exhibited excellent electrochemical performance, with a highly reversible capacity of 883 mAh g-1 after 130 cycles without any capacity loss, and a rapid C-rate capability of 500 mAh g-1 at 1C and 350 mAh g-1 at 3C.

Aromatic organic compounds hold potential as electrode materials in rechargeable batteries and could significantly impact the development of anode and cathode materials for sodium‐ion batteries (SIBs). Most aromatic organic compounds tested as anode materials for SIBs so far suffer from notable degradation under rapid charge/discharge cycles and exhibit poor long-term cycling performance. A novel molecular design concept has been introduced to enhance the stability of organic compounds used in battery electrodes. The compound in focus, [2.2.2.2]paracyclophane‐1,9,17,25‐tetraene (PCT), is designed to stabilize both its neutral state, through local aromaticity, and its doubly reduced state, via global aromaticity. This results in an anode material with exceptional cycling stability and superior performance during rapid charge/discharge cycles, offering an innovative avenue for advancing SIBs and other battery electrode materials.

Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2), known for its two-dimensional layered structure, is considered a promising anode material for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) due to its high theoretical capacity and affordability. However, challenges with MoS2 include low rate capability resulting from slow Na+ intercalation kinetics and poor cycling stability due to the stacking of MoS2 layers. In this study, a novel structure of bundled defect-rich MoS2 (BD-MoS2) is developed, featuring MoS2 with large vacancies, bundled by ultrathin MoO3, through a simple quenching process. When used as an anode in a SIB, the BD-MoS2 electrode demonstrates rapid charge/discharge processes owing to its pseudocapacitive-controlled Na+ storage mechanism. Experimental evidence and theoretical calculations reveal that Na+ can pass through the MoS2 layers via vacancies, not just along them, enabling three-dimensional Na+ diffusion with improved kinetics. Additionally, the bundling structure decreases layer stacking, resulting in exceptional cycle life and highly reversible capacities of 350 and 272 mAh g-1 at 2 and 5 A g-1 after 1000 cycles.

Hard carbon (HC) is considered the leading contender for anode materials in sodium-ion batteries. Various properties such as the intensity ratio of the Raman spectrum, the lateral size of HC crystallites (La), and the interlayer distance (d002) have been analyzed for their impact on anode performance. However, these properties do not directly represent the bulk characteristic of the Na+ intercalation reaction, as Raman analysis is highly surface-sensitive, and La and d002 only offer one-dimensional crystalline data. In this study, the crystallite interlayer area (Ai), determined using La, d002, and stacking height (Lc), is proposed to influence Na+ intercalation behavior in different HCs. It was discovered that various wood-derived HCs showed a similar total capacity of roughly 250 mAh g-1, yet the Na+ intercalation capacity (Ci) was directly proportional to Ai, with a correlation coefficient of R2 = 0.94. The evaluation factor Ai was also applicable to past studies and showed a strong correlation with their Ci, suggesting that Ai is more broadly applicable than traditional evaluation approaches.

A beneficial impact of the polyacrylic acid (PAA)-carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC) binder on improving the performance of an oxide-based anode has been documented in batteries. This led to the production of a range of oxide powders with exceptionally high capacity and cycling capability, a feat seldom accomplished previously, notably achieved in most cases without any particular carbon modification or morphology control.

Sodium is abundantly available worldwide, making sodium-ion rechargeable batteries advantageous over lithium-ion batteries for large-scale energy storage, assuming an appropriate host cathode for Na is discovered that meets required capacity, voltage, and cycle life at specified charge/discharge rates. Hexacyanometallates, being cost-effective, are promising cathode candidates due to their simple synthesis process and stable open framework that supports rapid Na(+) insertion and extraction. In this study, we present the notable influence of interstitial H2O on the structure and electrochemical properties of sodium manganese(II) hexacyanoferrates(II) with the nominal formula Na2MnFe(CN)6·zH2O (Na2-δMnHFC). The newly identified dehydrated Na2-δMnHFC phase demonstrates outstanding electrochemical performance compared to other Na-ion cathode materials previously reported. It delivers a reversible capacity of 150 mAh g(-1) at 3.5 V in a sodium half cell and 140 mAh g(-1) in a full cell with a hard-carbon anode. When charged/discharged at a rate of 20 C, the half-cell capacity reaches 120 mAh g(-1), and at 0.7 C, after 500 cycles, the cell retains 75% of its capacity.

Graphene-based nanomaterials have emerged as promising candidates for anode components in sodium-ion batteries, thanks to the unique properties of graphene and the synergistic interaction between graphene and active materials. Nevertheless, the 2D structure of graphene allows rapid sodium ion diffusion only in the parallel direction, while diffusion in the vertical direction is hindered, thereby reducing the rate capability of graphene-based electrodes. To address this limitation, pore-forming techniques have been applied to create perforations in graphene, facilitating the in situ growth of Co3Se4 nanoparticles. The creation of in-plane nanoholes disrupts the physical barriers of graphene nanosheets, enabling faster diffusion of electrolyte ions along the longitudinal direction. This design also prevents the aggregation of Co3Se4 nanoparticles due to their strong affinity for graphene. This innovative architecture, with enhanced conductivity and rapid ion transport, results in Co3Se4/holey graphene demonstrating an impressive rate performance of 519.5 mAh g−1 at 5.0 A g−1 and excellent cycle stability. The study concludes that improving sodium transport inside graphene-based composites is key to enhancing rate performance, and this approach is effective for modifying graphene-based nanomaterials for use as anode materials.

Developing anode electrodes for sodium-ion batteries presents challenges due to sluggish Na+ diffusion kinetics and significant volume expansion. Considerable efforts, including the development of carbon composites and innovative nanostructures, have been made to advance anode materials. In this study, an ultra-small few-layer MoS2 nanostructure was synthesized within a hierarchical porous carbon fiber composite using a nanocasting technique with a novel template. As an anode material, this composite exhibits excellent electrochemical performance in sodium-ion batteries, offering high reversible capacities (491 mA h g-1 after 50 cycles at 0.1 A g-1), impressive rate performance (387 mA h g-1 at 2 A g-1), and exceptional long-term cycling stability (234 mA h g-1 at 1 A g-1 after 3000 cycles). This represents one of the best long-term cycling performances noted for MoS2-based anode materials in sodium-ion batteries. This approach could provide new perspectives for creating high-performance anode materials for sodium-ion batteries.

Sodium ion batteries (SIBs) are garnering significant interest due to their potential for large-scale electrical grid regulation and the cost-effectiveness of sodium. Within this context, iron oxides (FeOx) are regarded as a highly promising anode option because of their high theoretical capacity and affordability. However, the use of FeOx anodes is hindered by slow reaction kinetics and substantial lattice fluctuations, resulting in poor rate performance and rapid capacity decline during the processes of sodiation and desodiation. In this research, Mn ions are incorporated into the Fe3O4 lattice at interstitial sites, creating Mn-incorporated Fe3O4/graphene (M-Fe3O4/G) composites via a simple hydrothermal method. XRD Rietveld refinement and first principle calculations confirm that Mn integration into the structure condenses the electron density near the Fermi level, enhancing electrical conductivity and electrochemical properties. Consequently, the M0.1Fe2.9O4/G composite achieves a high reversible capacity of 439.8 mAh g-1 at a current density of 100 mA g-1 over 200 cycles. At a higher current density of 1 A g-1, the M-Fe3O4/G composites remain stable for more than 1200 cycles, delivering a capacity of 210 mAh g-1. When paired with a Na3V2(PO4)3-type cathode, the Mn-incorporated Fe3O4/G composites show good performance in full SIBs (161.2 mAh g-1 at 1 A g-1 after 100 cycles). The adjustment of Mn ions within the Fe3O4 lattice offers valuable insights into optimizing metal oxide anode candidates for SIB applications.

Affordable and scalable sodium-ion (Na-ion) batteries offer a promising alternative to current lithium-ion batteries. To address their limited energy density, a practical solution involves developing a high-voltage, anode-free setup using a lightweight aluminum current collector on the anode and a high-voltage sodiumized cathode. This setup demands strict Na reversibility and high-voltage stability from the electrolyte. To meet these requirements, a 3A zeolite molecular sieve film is innovatively designed, creating a highly aggregated solvation structure through size effects. This effectively suppresses minor but continuous oxidative decomposition and enhances oxidative stability up to 4.5 V without compromising the Na reversibility of the anode (99.91%). Consequently, we achieve anode-free cells with high energy densities of 369 and 372 W h kg-1 for cells rated at 4.0 and 4.25 V, respectively. Moreover, this method ensures a long lifespan (250 cycles) for 4.0 V-class anode-free cells and significantly lowers costs in an eco-friendly manner.

Antimony- (Sb) based materials are regarded as promising anodes for sodium ion batteries (SIBs) due to their high theoretical capacities and suitable sodium insertion potentials. However, the energy density and cycling stability reported for Sb-based anodes in SIBs remain fairly restricted and require substantial enhancement. In this study, we introduce a novel Sb/C hybrid that encapsulates Sb nanorods within highly conductive nitrogen and sulfur codoped carbon (Sb@(N, S-C)) frameworks. As an SIB anode, the Sb@(N, S-C) hybrid achieves high reversible capacities, maintaining 621.1 mAh g^-1 at 100 mA g^-1 after 150 cycles, and 390.8 mAh g^-1 at 1 A g^-1 after 1000 cycles. At elevated current densities of 2, 5, and 10 A g^-1, this hybrid exhibits high reversible capacities of 534.4, 430.8, and 374.7 mAh g^-1, respectively. These outstanding sodium storage characteristics are primarily due to the distinctive cross-linked carbon networks that form highly conductive frameworks, enabling rapid ion and electron transfer, mitigating volume expansion, and preventing aggregation of Sb nanorods during cycling.

The introduction of oxygen vacancies in anatase TiO2 has been explored as a promising approach to enhance the transport of electrons and Na+ ions, which is vital for achieving superior electrochemical properties in anatase TiO2. Nonetheless, deliberately introducing oxygen vacancies in anatase TiO2 for sodium-ion anodes through a simple yet effective method remains a challenge. In this study, we present a novel approach to introduce oxygen vacancies into the urchin-like N-doped carbon-coated anatase TiO2 (NC-DTO) using a straightforward plasma treatment. The combination of oxygen vacancies and the conductive N-doped carbon coating significantly enhances the sodium storage performance of the resulting NC-DTO. When used as an anode for sodium-ion batteries, the NC-DTO electrode exhibits outstanding electrochemical performance (capacity: 272 mA h g-1 at 0.25 C, capacity retention: 98.8% after 5000 cycles at 10 C, and an ultra-high capacity: 150 mA h g-1 at 15 C). Density functional theory calculations and experimental findings suggest that the notable improvement in sodium storage performance of NC-DTO is attributed to the enhanced electronic conductivity from the N-doped carbon layer, alongside a narrowed band gap and reduced sodiation energy barrier from the introduced oxygen vacancies. This study underscores that employing plasma to introduce oxygen vacancies in TiO2 presents a promising strategy to enhance the electrochemical properties of TiO2, with potential applicability to various metal oxides in energy storage devices.

Recent research has highlighted black phosphorus (BP) as a promising anode material for sodium-ion batteries (SIB) due to its high theoretical capacity of 2596 mAh g^-1 and excellent electrical conductivity of approximately 300 S m^-1. Despite these advantages, the substantial volume change BP undergoes during electrochemical cycling poses challenges for its practical application. In this study, the reversible performance of BP in SIB is notably improved by covalently bonding functionalized BP to graphene. This chemical interaction enhances the stability of BP over extended cycling by improving its interface with graphene. The bridging lowers surface energy and allows for increased BP thickness, thereby expanding the channel between BP nanosheets and graphene. This expanded channel is capable of storing more sodium ions, enhancing cycling performance. Notably, two types of phosphorus-carbon bonds were identified for the first time during experimental analysis. As a result of this strategy, the BP-based SIB anode achieves a specific capacity of 1472 mAh g^-1 at 0.1 A g^-1 after 50 cycles and maintains 650 mAh g^-1 at 1 A g^-1 after 200 cycles.

Symmetric sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are emerging as promising options for large-scale energy storage due to their ease of production and the plentiful availability of sodium. Nevertheless, a significant challenge with most symmetric SIBs is their limited energy density. In this study, we synthesize a highly effective Na4V2(PO4)3 anode through electrochemical preintercalation. We construct a high energy density symmetric SIB using Na3V2(PO4)3 as the cathode and Na4V2(PO4)3 as the anode, exploiting the V4+/V2+ redox couple for the first time. In half-cell tests, both electrodes demonstrate stable electrochemical performance over 3000 cycles. These symmetric SIBs achieve an output voltage of 3.0 V and a cell-level energy density of 138 W h kg-1. Additionally, the sodium storage mechanism, analyzed over an extended voltage range of 0.01-3.9 V, is elucidated using in situ X-ray diffraction techniques.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are potential substitutes for lithium-ion batteries in large-scale energy storage due to the plentiful availability of sodium. Metal sulfides, as anode materials for SIBs, are attractive because they are cost-effective and environmentally friendly. In this study, a series of copper sulfides (Cu2S, Cu7S4, and Cu7KS4) are synthesized for the first time using a simple electrochemical method in KCl-NaCl-Na2S molten salts. The synthesized Cu2S, featuring a micron-sized flake structure, is evaluated as an SIB anode and achieves a capacity of 430 mAh g^-1 with a high initial Coulombic efficiency of 84.9% at a current density of 100 mA g^-1. Additionally, the Cu2S anode exhibits excellent performance with a capacity of 337 mAh g^-1 at 20 A g^-1 (equivalent to 50 C) and an ultralong cycle lifespan, retaining 88.2% capacity after 5000 cycles at 5 A g^-1, which corresponds to a fade rate of 0.0024% per cycle. The pseudocapacitance contribution and robust porous structure that form in situ during cycling enhance the Cu2S anodes' rate capability and cyclic stability, as demonstrated through kinetics analysis and ex situ characterization.

Sodium-ion batteries are an appealing choice for large-scale energy storage due to sodium's natural abundance and the low cost of its compounds. Phosphorus (P) is a desirable anode material for sodium-ion batteries, given its theoretical capacity of 2596 mAh/g. While red phosphorus (RP) has drawbacks such as lower electronic conductivity and initial Coulombic efficiency compared to black phosphorus (BP), BP's high cost and limited production hinder its use as an anode. To overcome these issues, we have created a straightforward, scalable method to synthesize a BP/graphene composite (BP/rGO) by applying pressure at room temperature. This method allows for producing carbon-black-free and binder-free BP/rGO anodes, which achieved specific charge capacities of 1460.1, 1401.2, 1377.6, 1339.7, 1277.8, 1123.78, and 720.8 mAh/g at current densities of 0.1, 0.5, 1, 5, 10, 20, and 40 A/g, respectively, in a rate capability test. In a cycling performance test, after 500 deep cycles, capacities of 1250 and 640 mAh/g were maintained at 1 and 40 A/g, respectively, representing a significant enhancement in performance for sodium-ion battery anodes.

A symmetric sodium-ion battery using an aqueous electrolyte has been demonstrated, employing NASICON-structured Na3MnTi(PO4)3 as both anode and cathode. This structure includes two electrochemically active transition metals, with Ti(4+)/Ti(3+) functioning on the anode side and Mn(3+)/Mn(2+) on the cathode side. The symmetric cell derived from this bipolar electrode material shows a distinct voltage plateau around 1.4 V in an aqueous electrolyte, along with stable cycling performance and excellent rate capability. The development of this aqueous symmetric sodium-ion battery offers a potentially safe and cost-effective solution for large-scale stationary energy storage.

Electrodes with enhanced sodium ion storage capabilities and cycling stability are crucial for boosting the energy density and rate capability of sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). In this study, we introduce a coral-like FeP composite featuring FeP nanoparticles anchored on a nitrogen-doped three-dimensional carbon framework (FeP@NC). The continuous N-doped carbon framework and a spring-buffering graphitized carbon layer surrounding the FeP nanoparticles enable the sodium-ion battery using the FeP@NC composite to demonstrate ultra-stable cycling performance at 10 A g⁻¹ with a capacity retention of 82.0% over 10,000 cycles. Notably, a particle refinement mechanism that increases capacity during cycling has been verified. Specifically, the FeP nanoparticles undergo a refining-recombination process in the first cycle, followed by a global refining trend through several cycles, resulting in an increased degree of graphitization and interface magnetization. This creates additional active sites for Na⁺ storage, leading to a capacity increase with continued cycling. This capacity enhancement phenomenon is also applicable to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs). This paper presents new insights into the mechanism of enhanced capacity during cycling and suggests a viable approach for designing high-performance anode materials for both SIBs and LIBs.

Creating hard carbon with both a high initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE) and excellent cycling stability is crucial for practical sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). However, defects and oxygen-containing groups inevitably form on the edges or layers of hard carbon, leading to a high number of irreversible Na+ sites, reducing efficiency and leading to battery failure. Therefore, eliminating these defect structures is vital for improving battery performance. Here, we present a method of applying a soft-carbon coating to free-standing hard-carbon electrodes, which significantly reduces the formation of defects and oxygen-containing groups on hard carbon. Electrochemical results indicate that these soft-carbon-coated, free-standing hard-carbon electrodes achieve an ultrahigh ICE of 94.1% and excellent cycling performance, maintaining 99% capacity retention after 100 cycles at a current density of 20 mA g-1. This demonstrates their strong potential for practical sodium storage systems. The sodium storage mechanism was also explored using operando Raman spectroscopy. We extend the "adsorption-intercalation-pore filling-deposition" model of sodium storage, suggesting that pore filling in the plateau region can be split into two stages: (1) sodium fills the pores near the carbon layer's inner wall; (2) as these inner wall pores near saturation, further sodium deposition occurs onto the existing sodium.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are emerging as strong contenders for large-scale energy storage systems, owing to the plentiful availability and widespread distribution of sodium resources. Effective solutions have been implemented to address issues associated with the large ion size of sodium at mid-to-low current densities. Nonetheless, there remains a substantial need for improved fast-charging capabilities in SIBs to meet the growing energy demands at larger and grid scales. In this study, a core-shell Co2VO4/carbon composite anode is developed to address the fast-charging issue in SIBs. The combination of the stable spinel structure of Co2VO4, the nanosphere size, and the carbon shell enhances Na+ ion diffusion, electron transfer rates, and electrochemical performance. At an ultrahigh current density of 5 A g-1, the Co2VO4@C anode achieved a capacity of 135.1 mAh g-1 with over 98% capacity retention after 2000 cycles, utilizing a pseudocapacitive dominant process. This research offers valuable insights into the design of fast-charging materials for SIBs and other battery technologies such as lithium-ion batteries.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are anticipated to become a viable commercial alternative to lithium-ion batteries for storing grid electricity, primarily due to their potentially lower cost in the near future. Currently, developing an appropriate anode material remains a significant challenge for SIB applications, especially at ambient temperature. Unlike lithium ions (Li+), graphite struggles to accommodate sodium ions (Na+) due to their larger ionic radius, whereas hard carbon with greater interlayer spacing shows promise with relatively high storage capacity and long-lasting cycle life. However, its low initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE) resulting from a large surface area and the high expense of synthesis limits practical use. This study introduces a novel coupled carbonization strategy for creating cost-effective hard carbon by pyrolyzing and carbonizing a mixture of abundant sucrose and phenolic resin. This process, optimized through detailed investigation, produces hard carbon with an exceptionally low surface area of 1.54 m² g⁻¹ and a high ICE of 87%, features rarely documented that significantly improve Na+ utilization in the cathode. Additionally, this hard carbon, boasting an interlayer distance of 3.95 Å, achieves a high capacity of 319 mAh g⁻¹ and retains 90% of its capacity over 150 cycles. A full cell featuring this hard carbon anode paired with an air-stable O3-Na0.9[Cu0.22Fe0.30Mn0.48]O2 cathode is also examined, displaying a high ICE of 80% and an energy density of 256 Wh kganode⁻¹ (against hard carbon) with dependable cycling performance. These findings confirm the feasibility and scalability of our synthetic strategy and suggest that tunable carbon-based materials have broad potential applications beyond their appealing characteristics in Na-ion batteries.

Sodium-ion batteries (NIBs) and potassium-ion batteries (KIBs) are promising alternatives to enhance lithium-ion (LIB) technology and expand the battery market. Hard carbon is a viable anode option for LIBs, NIBs, and KIBs due to its notable capacity, sustainability, availability, and stable physicochemical characteristics. In this study, a variety of hard carbons are produced via hydrothermal carbonization followed by pyrolysis at varying temperatures to precisely adjust their structural attributes. When used as anodes, these hard carbons show different ion-storage behaviors for Li, Na, and K, with NIBs demonstrating the highest reversible capacity. Comprehensive materials and electrochemical analyses are conducted to understand how structural features relate to electrochemical performance, elucidating the specific alkali-ion storage mechanisms in hard carbons. Furthermore, the top-performing hard carbon is paired with a sodium cathode Na3V2(PO4)3 in a Na-ion pouch cell, achieving a high power density of 2172 W kg−1 at an energy density of 181.5 Wh kg−1, based on the total active material weight in both the anode and cathode. This Na-ion pouch cell also shows stable, long-term cycling for 9000 hours or 5142 cycles, highlighting the potential of these materials as sustainable, scalable anodes for post-Li battery applications.

Sodium ion batteries (NIB, NAB, SIB) are garnering attention as a potentially cheaper alternative to lithium ion batteries (LIB), largely due to sodium's abundant and well-distributed global reserves. Among the promising anode materials for SIBs, tin can form alloys with up to 3.75 sodium atoms, yielding a charge storage capacity of 847 mAh g(-1). In this paper, we present the latest understanding of phase transformations caused by sodiation and their effects across different Sn-based systems, including metallic tin and its alloys, tin oxide (SnO2), tin sulfide (SnS2/SnS), and tin phosphide (Sn4P3). We begin by examining the known sodiation processes in metallic Sn, emphasizing new insights into reactions before forming the stable Na15Sn4 intermetallic compound. We discuss why equilibrium phase transitions, as represented in phase diagrams, do not manifest in this system, and instead, sodiation/desodiation occurs via a series of metastable crystalline and amorphous phases. Furthermore, we present recent modeling insights on how this phase transition affects the alloy's mechanical properties, shifting the bonding and nearest neighbor arrangement from "Sn-like" to "Na-like." We proceed to detail the sodiation reactions in SnO2, noting that while considerable experimentation focuses on synthesizing and testing tin oxide-based nanocomposites, the precise sodiation sequence is only beginning to be unraveled. Unlike Sn and Sn alloys, where near-theoretical capacities are achieved early in cycling, SnO2 fails to reach the 1398 mAh g(-1) capacity expected from a fully reversible conversion and alloying reaction. We underscore recent findings indicating that it is the Sn to Na15Sn4 alloying reaction that remains incomplete, thus capping the electrode's capacity. We also examine how the oxide conversion process passes through an intermediate SnO phase and how its reversibility in half-cells is heavily influenced by the terminal anodic voltage. We then explore the sodiation of tin sulfide and tin phosphide phases, noting emerging microstructural evidence that might clarify why neither sulfides nor phosphides reach their promising theoretical capacities under standard electrode testing conditions. Lastly, we offer a comprehensive comparison of capacity performance (cycling and rate) for various Sn-based anode materials, suggesting an optimal microstructural architecture may exist.

To address the issues of significant volume changes and low electronic conductivity in the earth-abundant ilmenite used for rechargeable Na-ion batteries (SIBs), a new anode composed of tiny ilmenite FeTiO3 nanoparticles embedded in carbon nanotubes (FTO⊂CNTs) has been successfully developed. This is achieved by applying a TiO2 shell on metal-organic framework (Fe-MOF) nanorods via sol-gel deposition, followed by solid-state annealing of these core-shell Fe-MOF@TiO2 structures, leading to the formation of the well-defined FTO⊂CNTs. The resulting FTO⊂CNT electrode showcases several distinct advantages: a hollow interior in the hybrid nanostructure, fully encapsulated ultrasmall electroactive units, a flexible conductive carbon matrix, and a stable solid electrolyte interface (SEI) of FTO during cycles. These electrodes exhibit excellent cycling stability (358.8 mA h g-1 after 200 cycles at 100 mA g-1) and impressive rate capability (201.8 mA h g-1 at 5000 mA g-1) with a high Coulombic efficiency of around 99%. Furthermore, when paired with the typical Na3V2(PO4)3 cathode to form full SIBs, the resulting FTO⊂CNT//Na3V2(PO4)3 batteries demonstrate superior rate capability and an extended cycle life.

A graphite-Si composite anode for Li-ion batteries was developed by synthesizing silicon nanoparticles (Si NPs) on graphite microparticles using a polymer blend of poly(diallyl dimethyl-ammonium chloride) and poly(sodium 4-styrenesulfonate). This polymer blend achieved a consistent distribution of Si NPs and formed a durable artificial solid-electrolyte interphase, significantly improving both cycle stability and rate performance of the composite electrode. The electrode demonstrated a specific capacity of 450 mA h g(-1) with 96% capacity retention at a 10 C-rate, 95% retention after 200 cycles, and exhibited expansion behavior similar to that of a pristine graphite electrode.

Sodium-ion batteries are highly regarded as promising options for large-scale energy storage due to the plentiful supply and low cost of sodium. Their development and market potential, however, are contingent on employing high-capacity electrode materials. SnO2, among various metal oxides, offers a high theoretical specific capacity for sodium-ion batteries, but its practical application is challenged by significant volume expansion and poor electrical conductivity. Although numerous studies have explored different nanostructured designs, including SnO2 nanocomposites, the influence of other cell components, such as electrolyte and binder, on specific capacity and cyclic stability remains unclear. This study examines the combined effects of electrolyte and binder to enhance the performance of SnO2 supported on a hybrid network of reduced graphene oxide and partially open multiwalled carbon nanotubes as an anode for sodium-ion batteries. Our findings indicate that using sodium carboxyl methyl cellulose as a binder and ethylene carbonate/diethyl carbonate as the electrolyte solvent results in a high specific capacity of 688 mAh g–1 and reliable cyclic stability over 500 cycles—representing a 56% increase in specific capacity compared to using a poly(vinylidene fluoride) binder and propylene carbonate as the electrolyte solvent. This study advances the understanding of the synergistic influence of electrolyte and binder in developing metal-oxide-based electrode materials to promote the commercialization of sodium-ion batteries.

A straightforward one-step thermal pyrolysis method has been devised to produce a carbon membrane from a natural leaf. The resulting carbonized leaf membrane features anisotropic surfaces and internal hierarchical porosity, offering a specific capacity of 360 mAh/g and an initial Coulombic efficiency of 74.8% as a binder-free, current-collector-free anode for rechargeable sodium ion batteries. Additionally, by stacking and carbonizing leaves, large-area carbon membranes with low contact resistance are fabricated, representing a promising approach for large-scale development of sodium-ion batteries.

Bismuth (Bi), as a two-dimensional material, has a significant interlayer spacing along the c-axis (0.395 nm), which offers numerous active sites for sodium ions, ensuring high activity for sodium ion storage. Despite this, Bi's low electrical conductivity and poor cycling performance hinder its practical usability. In this study, we synthesized Bi microspheres coated with nitrogen-doped carbon (Bi@NC). Thanks to the distinctive Bi crystals and the nitrogen-doped carbon coating, the Bi@NC anode demonstrated excellent cycling stability and superior rate performance. Furthermore, when the Bi@NC anode was paired with a Na₃V₂(PO₄)₃@C cathode in a full battery, it delivered remarkable sodium storage performance, maintaining 57 mA h g⁻¹ after 2000 cycles at a current density of 1.0 A g⁻¹.

Sodium-ion batteries are increasingly seen as a cost-effective replacement for lithium-ion systems in large-scale energy storage, yet their safety remains a significant concern for practical use. This study presents a safer sodium-ion battery by using a nonflammable phosphate electrolyte, specifically trimethyl phosphate (TMP), paired with a NaNi0.35Mn0.35Fe0.3O2 cathode and an Sb-based alloy anode. We examine the TMP electrolyte's physical and electrochemical compatibilities through tests such as ignition, ionic conductivity, cyclic voltammetry, and charge-discharge cycles. The findings reveal that the TMP electrolyte with FEC additive is entirely nonflammable and provides a wide electrochemical window (0–4.5 V vs. Na/Na+), where both the Sb-based anode and NaNi0.35Mn0.35Fe0.3O2 cathode deliver high reversible capacity and cycle stability, akin to performance in a carbonate electrolyte. From these findings, we develop a nonflammable sodium-ion battery using an Sb anode, NaNi0.35Mn0.35Fe0.3O2 cathode, and TMP + 10 vol% FEC electrolyte that functions effectively with notable capacity and cyclability, indicating a promising future for safer sodium-ion batteries in large-scale energy storage applications.

Structural phase transitions are valued in technology because they can modify a material's properties without introducing new elements. It has been discovered that the hexagonal-SnS2 phase can change into the orthorhombic-SnS phase when subjected to annealing in an argon atmosphere. The transformed SnS demonstrates improved sodium-ion storage capabilities compared to SnS2, thanks to its structural benefits. This study introduces a novel SnS@graphene architecture for use as a sodium-ion battery anode, comprising two-dimensional SnS and graphene nanosheets as complementary components. The synthesized SnS@graphene hybrid nanostructured composite achieves an outstanding specific capacity of 940 mAh g(-1) and notable rate capabilities of 492 and 308 mAh g(-1) after 250 cycles at current densities of 810 and 7290 mA g(-1), respectively. This performance surpasses that of most known Na-ion battery anode materials. Detailed discussions using ex situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and ex situ X-ray diffraction reveal the formation mechanism of SnS@graphene and the synergistic sodium-storage reactions of SnS at the anode. During sodiation, SnS undergoes a two-phase structural transition (orthorhombic-SnS to cubic-Sn to orthorhombic-Na3.75Sn), whereas SnS2 follows a three-phase transformation (hexagonal-SnS2 to tetragonal-Sn to orthorhombic-Na3.75Sn). The minimal structural alterations in SnS during conversion are expected to contribute to its robust structural and cycling stability in sodium-ion battery applications. These findings establish that the SnS@graphene architecture possesses distinctive features ideal for high-performance energy storage solutions.

Sodium-ion batteries are viewed as a highly promising alternative to lithium-ion batteries for large-scale energy storage applications. However, advancing these batteries requires the development of new anode materials, as key materials used in lithium-ion batteries, like graphite and silicon, prove unsuitable for sodium-ion use. We have developed innovative SnS/C nanocomposites using a top-down approach for use as anodes in sodium-ion batteries. These nanocomposites exhibit greatly enhanced electrochemical performance compared to unmodified SnS, particularly in cycling stability and rate capabilities. The SnS/C nanocomposites demonstrate impressive capacity retention over various current rates and can achieve capacities of up to 400 mA h g−1, even at the elevated current density of 800 mA g−1 (2C). To elucidate the reaction mechanisms of the SnS/C nanocomposites, we conducted ex situ transmission electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, and operando X-ray absorption near edge structure studies.

The rising popularity of sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) has intensified interest in developing economical anode materials, such as metal oxides, for Na-ion storage. Most metal oxide electrodes fail to perform as effectively in SIBs as in Li-ion batteries due to the significantly larger ion radius of Na compared to Li. This study employs iron oxide to illustrate that thoughtfully designing an amorphous structure can enhance the Na-ion storage capabilities of metal oxides. Amorphous Fe2O3/graphene composite nanosheets (Fe2O3@GNS) were synthesized using a simple method for use as anodes in SIBs. The results show that amorphous Fe2O3 nanoparticles, averaging 5 nm in diameter, are evenly distributed on graphene nanosheets through a strong C-O-Fe oxygen-bridge bond. Compared to crystalline Fe2O3, the amorphous Fe2O3@GNS demonstrated superior sodium storage properties, including high electrochemical activity, an initial Coulombic efficiency of 81.2%, and excellent rate performance. At 100 mA/g, the amorphous Fe2O3@GNS composites achieve a specific capacity of 440 mAh/g, surpassing the crystalline Fe2O3 specific capacity of 284 mAh/g. Even at 2 A/g, they maintain a high specific capacity of 219 mAh/g. This exceptional electrochemical performance arises from the amorphous Fe2O3 structure and strong interfacial interaction with GNS, which together accommodate more active sites, enhance sodium ion transmission, improve electron transfer, and effectively buffer volume changes during sodiation and desodiation. This approach to designing amorphous iron oxide anodes for SIBs may also aid in developing other metal oxide amorphous nanostructures to enhance their Na-ion storage performance.

The solid-electrolyte interface (SEI) film in sodium-ion batteries is crucial for the battery's capacity retention and cycling stability. Despite its importance, there is limited research on the SEI film specific to sodium-ion batteries, and the formation mechanism remains unclear. This study uses DFT to examine the reduction mechanisms of several solvents and additives, including ethylene carbonate (EC), propylene carbonate (PC), vinylene carbonate (VC), ethylene sulfite (ES), 1,3-propylene sulfite (PS), and fluorinated ethylene carbonate (FEC). Calculations of reaction activation energies, Gibbs free energies, enthalpies, and transition state structures were performed. The results indicate that VC, ES, and PS additives are more prone to form organic components in the anode SEI film through one-electron reduction. The preference for one-electron reduction to create organic SEI is VC>PC>EC, while for two-electron reduction resulting in the inorganic Na2CO3 component, the order is EC>PC>VC. Moreover, the formation of inorganic Na2SO3 from ES and PS via two-electron reduction is more challenging compared to carbonate esters. Additionally, the FEC is more likely to undergo both one- and two-electron reductive decomposition to produce inorganic NaF components.

To advance lithium and sodium ion battery technology, it is crucial to comprehend how the chemical structures of various components influence their properties. Operando structural studies provide valuable insights into battery operation, yet distinguishing the contributions of different battery stack components (such as electrodes, current collectors, electrolytes, and binders) to analyze specific materials remains challenging. Leveraging operando X-ray diffraction computed tomography (XRD-CT), we investigated specific components within a largely unaltered operating cell, extracting intricate, spatially-resolved structural data on both crystalline and amorphous phases involved during cycling through Rietveld and pair distribution function (PDF) methods. We apply this approach to conduct the inaugural detailed structural analysis of sodium cycling in a phosphorus anode, uncovering unexpectedly distinct mechanisms for sodiation and desodiation in this high-capacity, promising anode system.

All-solid-state sodium ion batteries (AS3iBs) are in demand for stationary energy storage applications due to their robust safety and stability across a broad temperature range. Hard carbon (HC), known for its low cost, low redox potential, and high capacity, plays a crucial role in developing feasible large-scale sodium-ion batteries. Nonetheless, the energy density of batteries using this anode material suffers from a low initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE). In this study, two methods were investigated to enhance the ICE of pristine HC: i) additional pyrolysis and ii) presodiation through thermal decomposition of NaBH4. Techniques such as Raman spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and electrochemical analyses reveal that thermal treatment increases the Csp2 content in the HC, while presodiation provides sodium to occupy intrinsic irreversible sites. As a result, presodiated HC demonstrates an impressive ICE (>99%) compared to thermally treated HC (90%) and pristine HC (83%) in half-cell setups. Significantly, the AS3iB utilizing presodiated HC as the anode and NaCrO2 as the cathode achieves a high ICE of 92% and an initial discharge energy density of 294 Wh kg_cathode^−1.

High gravimetric and volumetric energy density storage devices are crucial due to the fast advancement of electric vehicles and portable and wearable electronics. Electrospinning holds promise for creating freestanding electrodes with these high energy densities. However, traditional electrospun electrodes are limited by the low mass loading of active materials, typically between 20% and 30% by weight. In this study, a biomimetic approach, inspired by sticky spider webs, is used to develop a high-performance anode that enhances both gravimetric and volumetric energy densities. Freestanding carbon nanofiber (CNF) membranes with over 50% by weight of bismuth were created via electrospinning followed by thermal processing. These membranes feature CNF network structures closely bonded with active bismuth clusters, providing robust mechanical protection and enabling rapid charge transport—a challenging combination. As a lithium-ion battery anode, the composite membrane offers a high reversible capacity of 483 mA h g-1 at 100 mA g-1 after 200 cycles and excellent rate performance of 242 mA h g-1 at 1 A g-1. For sodium ion battery use, it demonstrates a high reversible specific capacity of 346 mA h g-1 and impressive cycling stability, maintaining 186 mA h g-1 at 50 mA g-1 after 100 cycles. This study presents a straightforward, cost-effective, and environmentally friendly method for producing freestanding and binder-free composite electrodes with high active material loading, suitable for use in LIBs and SIBs.

Hard carbon (HC) shows promise as a commercially viable anode material for use in both lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). Nevertheless, existing methods for evaluating battery performance that are focused on...

Two-dimensional (2D) molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) has garnered significant attention for applications in catalysis, energy storage, and electronics. Nonetheless, the absence of efficient exfoliation techniques for large-scale production of 2D materials has hindered practical applications. We present an easy liquid-phase exfoliation method that enhances the exfoliation efficiency of single-layer MoS2 sheets using 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP) with the assistance of sodium hydroxide (NaOH). This method significantly increases the concentration of exfoliated MoS2 nanosheets compared to traditional liquid-phase exfoliation techniques employing NMP solvent. We demonstrate the stable performance of sodium-ion batteries using the exfoliated MoS2 and MoS2-reduced graphene oxide (MoS2-rGO) composite as anode materials.

The application of oxygen vacancies (OVs) in sodium ion batteries (SIBs) is anticipated to boost performance, yet it has been infrequently documented. Using the MoO(3-x) nanosheet anode as a model, we demonstrate for the first time the advantages of OVs on SIB performance. Additionally, these benefits under deep-discharge conditions can be further enhanced by an ultrathin Al2O3 coating. Various measurements indicate that OVs improve electric conductivity and the Na-ion diffusion coefficient, while the ultrathin coating effectively reduces cycling-induced solid-electrolyte interphase. The coated nanosheets showed high reversible capacity and excellent rate capability, achieving capacities of 283.9 mAh g(-1) at 50 mA g(-1) and 179.3 mAh g(-1) at 1 A g(-1) after 100 cycles. This study may not only draw increased interest in OVs for sodium energy storage but also introduce new opportunities for designing strategies to exploit defects in other energy storage systems.

Heterostructure engineering is emerging as a highly effective strategy to enhance the slow kinetics of anodes in sodium ion batteries (SIBs). This study presents a comprehensive analysis of how different heterostructure interfaces impact the rate performance of discharge products (Na2O, Na2S, Na2Se). First-principle calculations indicate that the Na2S/Na2Se interface has the lowest diffusion energy barrier (0.39 eV) for Na ions among the three interface types (Na2O/Na2S, Na2O/Na2Se, and Na2S/Na2Se), attributed to its minimal interface deformation, and similar electronegativity and lattice constant. Experimental findings demonstrate that a metal sulfide/metal selenide (SnS/SnSe2) hierarchical anode achieves exceptional rate performance, with a normalized capacity of 45.6% at a high rate of 10 A g-1 compared to 0.1 A g-1. This design strategy offers valuable insights for crafting anodes with high rate performance for advanced battery systems.

Antimony/carbon (Sb@C) microspheres are initially prepared using an uncomplicated self-catalyzing solvothermal approach, and their potential as anode materials in sodium-ion batteries is studied. Structural and morphological analyses show that the Sb@C microspheres consist of Sb nanoparticles (approximately 20 nm in size) uniformly encased within the carbon matrix. Comparative experiments with various raw materials confirm the self-catalyzing solvothermal process. The resultant Sb@C microspheres display excellent sodium storage capabilities, with a reversible capacity of 640 mAh g(-1), outstanding rate performance, and enduring cycling stability with 92.3% capacity retention over 300 cycles, highlighting their promise as anode materials for sodium-ion batteries.

Na-based layered transition metal oxides with an O3-type configuration are viewed as promising options for cathodes in sodium-ion batteries. Nevertheless, they face issues of rapid capacity decline and poor rate performance due to significant structural alterations and interfacial degradation. This research details the synthesis of a NaPO3 surface-modified O3-type layered NaNi1/3 Fe1/3 Mn1/3 O2 cathode, which exhibits enhanced stability at high voltages by protecting against acid degradation, accomplished via a solid-gas reaction between cathode particles and gaseous P2O5. The NaPO3 nanolayer on the surface effectively maintains the crystal structure by reducing surface parasitic reactions and elevating the average voltage. The modified cathode demonstrates superior cyclic stability (80.1% compared to 63.6%) after 150 cycles at 1 C within the voltage range of 2.0 V-4.2 V (vs Na+/Na). Additionally, due to the intrinsic ionic conduction of NaPO3, the modified cathode shows excellent rate capability (103 mAh g^-1 compared to 60 mAh g^-1) at 10 C. This study highlights a practically significant method for advancing sodium-ion battery technology with improved rate performance and durability.

Introducing heteroatoms can effectively inhibit phase transitions in layered sodium-ion battery cathodes, yet the behavior of these heteroatoms under operating conditions remains not fully understood at the atomic level. This study combines density functional theory calculations with experimental methods to investigate the mitigation behavior and mechanisms of Mg dopants in P2-Na0.67Ni0.33Mn0.67O2 under operating conditions. Upon Na extraction, voids can move some Mg dopants from the TM layers into the Na layers. When the Mg concentration is relatively high in the TM layer, multiple Mg ions tend to diffuse collectively, eventually leading to Mg-rich regions (i.e., Mg segregation) that form away from Ni vacancies. This Mg segregation induced by the void-pump effect effectively curtails the P2-O2 phase transition due to the stronger electrostatic Mg-O attraction, which solidifies the integration between two adjacent oxygen layers and curbs crack growth by reducing lattice volume changes during high-voltage cycles. This research provides essential insight into heteroatom mitigation behavior in layered cathodes on an atomic scale, contributing to the development of next-generation energy storage technologies.

Sodium (Na) ion batteries (SIBs) offer the potential for cost-effective energy storage systems but are hindered by inadequate energy density. Incorporating oxygen (O) redox in the design of Na-storage cathodes is currently seen as a promising method to add extra capacity and address the energy density issue. The challenge lies in overcoming the irreversible electrochemical behavior resulting from O release. Additionally, the O redox chemistry and its related structural changes remain unclear. This paper examines the O redox mechanism in Na-storage transition metal oxides. We summarize the challenges related to reaction irreversibility and structural degradation using advanced characterization techniques. Furthermore, we discuss strategies that may improve the electrochemical characteristics of O redox and propose future research directions for exploring viable O redox cathode materials.

The P2‐type layered oxide Na2/3Ni1/3Mn2/3O2 is a promising candidate for use in sodium‐ion batteries (SIBs). It is, however, hindered by a significant P2–O2 phase transition during charging to high voltages, leading to substantial volume changes and poor cycling stability. In this study, a Quasi‐zero strain cathode, P2‐Na0.75Li0.15Mg0.05Ni0.1Mn0.7O2, is synthesized, showing a negligible P2–O2 transition with a minimal volume change of just 0.49%. This results in superior cycling performance, with 83.9% capacity retention after 500 cycles at 5 C. The reduced volume strain stems from two factors: (1) the presence of Mg2+ within the Na layer acts as a "pillar," stabilizing the crystal structure when sodium is removed and minimizing structural changes at high voltage. (2) The incorporation of Li+ into the transition metal (TM) layer alleviates electron localization in the highly desodiated state and effectively anchors the coordination of oxygen atoms, thereby preventing the slip associated with the P2–O2 transition. This research not only sheds light on the synergistic effect of Li and Mg substitution for enhancing the structural stability of P2‐type cathodes but also offers a strategic approach for developing SIB cathodes with exceptionally low bulk strain.

Prussian blue is garnering considerable interest as a potential sodium-ion battery cathode due to its open framework structure and high operational voltage. Nonetheless, its practical application in sodium-ion batteries is hindered by the presence of interstitial water in its crystalline framework and its low electronic conductivity. In this study, acid-assisted ball milling synthesis was utilized as a flexible approach to produce surface-modified Prussian blue. Utilizing (CH3COO)2Fe as the starting material, the ball milling synthesis yielded Prussian blue with surface modification via the carboxyl functional group, leading to reduced interstitial water and improved electrochemical cycling performance. Moreover, this synthesis method imparted a large surface area to the Prussian blue, thereby enhancing its electrochemical rate performance. When employed as a sodium-ion battery cathode, the synthesized Prussian blue achieved a specific capacity of 145.3 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C and 113.7 mAh g−1 at 1 C, retaining 54.5% of the initial capacity after 1000 cycles at 1 C (1 C equates to 170 mA g−1). Additionally, a solid-state sodium-ion battery was assembled using the prepared Prussian blue as the cathode and Na metal as the anode, achieving a specific capacity of 128.7 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C. This study proposes a viable solution to mitigate the challenges of Prussian blue for commercial purposes.

P2-type layered oxides composed of Fe and Mn show promise as sodium ion battery (SIB) cathode materials due to their cost-effective metal components and high specific capacity. However, they encounter issues of rapid capacity loss and complex phase transitions. This research focuses on adjusting the crystal structure and enhancing the electrochemical properties of Na0.67Mn0.5Fe0.5O2 through Al doping for Mn or Fe, to better understand Al's role in improving rate capability and cycling performance. (1) Replacing Mn or Fe with Al reduces lattice parameters a and c, increases d spacing, and lengthens Na-O bonds, thereby boosting Na+ diffusion and rate capability, especially in Na0.67Mn0.5Fe0.47Al0.03O2. (2) Al doping decreases TMO2 thickness and reinforces TM-O/O-O bonding, thereby improving layered structure stability and capacity retention. (3) It also reduces Mn3+ presence and Jahn-Teller distortion, addressing irreversible phase transitions. (4) Furthermore, Al doping lessens lattice volume changes and structural strain, enhancing the layered structure's stability and cycling performance, particularly when substituting Al for Fe. The detailed understanding of Al substitution can aid in crafting high-performance SIB cathode materials through strategic lattice doping.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are promising for large-scale energy storage applications. P2-type manganese-based layered oxides have drawn attention due to their high theoretical capacity, affordability, and environmental compatibility. However, their susceptibility to water and limited cycling stability pose challenges, and the mechanisms behind these issues remain unclear. This study employs copper substitution to mitigate the Jahn-Teller effect of Mn3+ and modify the associated lattice structure. A detailed examination of water sensitivity and charge compensation mechanisms is conducted. Findings indicate that water sensitivity in the electrode is connected to the Na+/vacancy order in the Na interlayers, as water molecules insert more readily into electrodes in the charged state. However, the water uptake does not increase corresponding to Na+ extraction. Additionally, Mn2+ forms at the electrode surface during initial discharge, while redox reactions in the bulk mainly occur between Mn3+ and Mn4+. Copper substitution in the transition metal layer influences Na+/vacancy arrangement and reduces Mn2+ formation on the Na0.7Mn0.9Cu0.1O2 electrode, leading to enhanced air stability and improved storage properties.

In O3-type sodium-ion battery (SIB) cathodes, phase transitions and lattice parameter changes of the O3 structure typically occur, which can increase voltage hysteresis and reduce energy efficiency. Considering that cost is a key barrier for the widespread use of SIBs in large-scale energy storage, we examine Co/Ni-free NaxCu0.18Fe0.3Mn0.52O2 (x = 0.8, 0.85, 0.9) and introduce an effective strategy to minimize voltage hysteresis. It is determined that when the Na content is 0.8, the material achieves its highest energy efficiency of 95.4% after activation (within 2.5-4.0 V, at 50 mA g-1, on the 50th cycle), along with excellent capacity retention (approximately 0.056% decay per cycle). Further analyses indicate that Na0.8Cu0.18Fe0.3Mn0.52O2 undergoes a smooth O3-P3 phase transition and does not experience lattice parameter changes typical of O3 phases. The essential factor is the feasibility of forming the O3/P3 composite in this material. This work presents a straightforward strategy for designing O3-type cathodes with high energy efficiency and may inspire the development of layered oxides with higher O3/P3 Na content through elemental modifications.

Layered O3-type sodium oxides (NaMO2, where M represents a transition metal) typically experience an O3-P3 phase transition at a relatively low redox voltage of approximately 3 V (vs. Na+/Na) during the extraction and insertion of sodium. Consequently, nearly half of their total capacity is confined to this low voltage range, limiting their efficacy as cathode materials for sodium-ion batteries (NIBs) due to insufficient energy density. This makes the creation of high-voltage O3-type cathodes particularly difficult, as increasing the phase-transition voltage through structural modifications poses significant challenges. Here we present a novel example of O3-type sodium insertion materials for use in NIBs. The engineered O3-type Na0.7 Ni0.35 Sn0.65 O2 material achieves a redox potential as high as 3.7 V (vs. Na+/Na), marking the highest reported for O3-type materials based on the Ni2+/Ni3+ couple. This achievement is attributed to enhanced Ni-O bond ionicity, which results from a diminished orbital overlap between the transition metals and oxygen within the MO2 layers.
