This research offers an orbital-level perspective on the operating potentials of the nominal redox couples for O3-NaMO2 cathodes, providing a strategy that can be utilized to design electrodes with enhanced performance.

Sodium-ion batteries (SiB) are regarded as a viable alternative to existing Lithium-ion batteries (LiBs). Nevertheless, SiB represent an emerging technology still in its early developmental phase with a broad array...

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) offer a promising solution for cost-effective and safe energy storage to meet large-scale energy demands. In this study, we developed manganese oxide (α-MnO2) nanorods for SIB applications. We conducted a systematic examination of the crystal structure, which is essential for high-performance energy storage, focusing on the metal oxide cathode. The incorporation of sodium into the α-MnO2 framework was analyzed using theoretical density functional theory (DFT) studies. These studies indicate that Na ions exhibit easy diffusion kinetics through the MnO2 lattice, with a notably low diffusion barrier of 0.21 eV. As a cathode material for SIBs, MnO2 demonstrated a moderate capacity of 109 mAh·g–1 at a C/20 current rate and excellent cyclic stability, retaining 58.6% capacity after 800 cycles in NaPF6/EC+DMC (5% FEC) electrolyte. It also achieved a higher capacity of 181 mAh·g–1 at the same current rate in NaClO4/PC (5% FEC) electrolyte, although it experienced rapid capacity decline, losing 11.5% after 800 cycles. Our results suggest that the high crystallinity and hierarchical nanorod morphology of MnO2 contribute to improved cycling performance, together with fast and continuous charge-discharge characteristics.

Layered manganese-based cathode materials are promising for sodium ion batteries due to their high specific capacities. However, they are affected by the Jahn-Teller effect and unavoidable phase transitions, which hinder cycling stability and rate capability. In this study, a P2-type manganese oxide nanoplate cathode material modified with Mo-substitution, featuring an oriented stacking structure and exposed {010} active facets, is presented. This modified manganese oxide nanoplate cathode retains 87.8% of its capacity after 1200 cycles at a rate of 10C (2000 mA g-1). It also achieves a specific power density of up to 530 W Kg-1, with a specific discharge capacity of 143.9 mA h g-1 at 1C and maintains 89.6% capacity retention over 100 cycles. The enhanced electrochemical performance is linked to the efficient chemical modification and unique structural attributes of the manganese oxide nanoplate. Mo-substitution increases the lattice space and average oxidation state, facilitating Na+ diffusion, which reduces the Jahn-Teller effect and boosts structural stability, resulting in an exceptionally long cycling lifespan. The multilayer oriented stacking nanoplate structure with exposed {010} active facets offers more surface active sites and shortens the Na+ diffusion path, enhancing the rate capability.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are being recognized as a promising addition to lithium-ion batteries, capable of diversifying the battery market. Nevertheless, a major challenge remains in developing cathode materials that offer both high-rate performance and long-cycle stability for SIBs. To address this, a method is presented that enhances these properties by incorporating an ordered bicontinuous porous structure into the cathode materials of SIBs. Prussian blue analogues (PBAs) are chosen for this purpose, as they are considered among the most promising cathode materials for SIBs. The introduction of 3D continuous channels facilitates rapid Na+ ion diffusion, alongside the inherent mechanical robustness of the bicontinuous architecture. These PBAs demonstrate impressive rate capability (80 mAh g−1 at 2.5 A g−1) and an extremely long cycling life (over 3000 cycles at 0.5 A g−1), achieving leading performance among reported PBA-based cathode materials. This research paves the way for improving slow ion diffusion kinetics in battery electrodes and offers a new solution to the problem of electrode failure caused by high-stress concentration during ion storage.

In lithium-ion battery layered oxide cathodes, cation migration is frequently observed due to the similar ionic radii of lithium and transition metals (TMs). Despite the significant difference in ionic radii between sodium and TMs, TMs in layered sodium-ion battery (SIB) cathodes can still move to the sodium layer, causing significant electrochemical degradation. To understand the cause of TM migration in layered SIB cathodes, we study NaCrO2, a common layered cathode experiencing severe TM migration, as a model. We discover that TM migration originates from random desodiation and the ensuing development of a sodium-free layer at high charge potentials. To tackle this problem, a Ru/Ti co-doping strategy is proposed. In this approach, the active Ru dopant is oxidized first to enable selective desodiation, while the inactive Ti dopant acts as a pillar, preventing full desodiation in Ru-containing TM layers. This strategy reduces the formation of Na-free layers and subsequently enhances electrochemical performance.

P2-type Na2/3Ni1/3Mn2/3O2 (NNMO) is a promising cathode material for sodium-ion batteries, offering theoretically high capacity and working voltage for substantial energy storage. However, its cycling stability is compromised due to an undesirable P2-O2 phase transition. To address this, Fe3+ ions are incorporated into the NNMO lattice, creating Na2/3Ni1/3Mn2/3-xFexO2 (x = 0, 1/24, 1/12, 1/8, 1/6) which effectively stabilizes the P2-type structure. In these Fe-substituted compositions, both Ni2+/Ni4+ and Fe3+/Fe4+ redox couples engage in the reactions, thereby curbing the P2-O2 transition, as confirmed by ex situ X-ray diffraction. Consequently, the optimized Na2/3Ni1/3Mn7/12Fe1/12O2 (1/12-NNMF) demonstrates enduring cycling stability, with a fading rate of just 0.05% per cycle over 300 cycles at 5 C. Additionally, 1/12-NNMF exhibits outstanding rate performance (65 mA h g-1 at 25 C) and excellent low-temperature capacity retention of 94% after 80 cycles at -25 °C, attributed to improved Na diffusion due to Fe doping, as shown by electrode kinetics studies. Notably, 1/12-NNMF also shows exceptional full-cell performance when paired with an LS-Sb@G anode, suggesting its potential for practical applications.

Sodium ion batteries offer benefits for large-scale energy storage, including being cost-effective and safer. Nevertheless, traditional anode materials like graphite fall short due to the large Na+ ion radius, which complicates their insertion and extraction during charging and discharging cycles. A recent development is the synthesis of biphenylene network (BPN), a two-dimensional carbon structure. This study explores BPN's viability as a sodium storage medium. Theoretical analyses demonstrate BPN's advantages as a sodium battery anode, with a maximum specific capacity of 413 mA h g-1, surpassing the 372 mA h g-1 of the graphite-Li system. BPN features a low Na+ diffusion barrier (under 0.6 eV) and minimal volume expansion during charging (approximately 26%), outperforming the graphite-Na system. Our results offer new perspectives on Na storage in BPN and guide the application of BPN anodes in sodium ion batteries.

Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) is seen as a promising anode material for future sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) due to its high theoretical capacity. Nevertheless, its practical use is limited by low conductivity, significant volume changes, and undesirable phase transformations. This study introduces a hierarchically structured core-shell heterostructure composed of nitrogen-doped MoS2/C and silicon oxycarbide (SiOC) (N-MoS2/C@SiOC), produced through the simple pyrolysis of a suspension consisting of an N-MoS2/polyfurfural precursor in silicone oil. The incorporation of nitrogen into the two-dimensional MoS2 structure with carbon results in increased interlayer spacing and better electronic conductivity and mechanical stability, facilitating the easy and highly reversible insertion and removal of sodium ions during cycling. Additionally, the nanoscale SiOC shell with its surface capacitive reactivity creates a conductive network that prevents adverse side reactions at the electrode/electrolyte interface and serves as a buffer to mitigate severe volume expansion. Consequently, the N-MoS2/C@SiOC composite demonstrates high reversible capacity (540.7 mAh g-1), excellent capacity retention (>100% after 200 cycles), and outstanding rate capability up to 10 A g-1. The straightforward hierarchical core-shell design strategy presented in this research enables the creation of high-performance metal sulfide anodes and other high-capacity anode materials suitable for energy storage applications.

SnS2 materials have gained significant attention in electrochemical energy storage due to their layered structure offering high specific capacity. However, their tendency to restack during charge/discharge cycles can cause electrode structure instability and reduced capacity. This paper presents a straightforward one-step hydrothermal method to synthesize a SnS2/graphene/SnS2 (SnS2/rGO/SnS2) composite. This composite features ultrathin SnS2 nanosheets covalently attached on both sides of reduced graphene oxide sheets through C‒S bonds. The inclusion of graphene between two SnS2 layers results in an expanded interlayer spacing of approximately 8.03 Å, which aids the insertion/extraction of Li+/Na+ ions with rapid transport kinetics, while preventing the restacking of SnS2 nanosheets during cycling. Density functional theory calculations indicate the most stable state is the moderate interlayer spacing of this sandwich-like composite. The diffusion coefficients of Li/Na ions derived from both molecular simulations and experimental data confirm this state is optimal for quick ion transport. Additionally, numerous ultra-small SnS2 nanoparticles fixed on the graphene sheets enhance the composite's pseudocapacitive contribution, particularly at high current densities, ensuring excellent performance with specific capacities of 844 and 765 mAh g⁻¹ for Li/Na-ion batteries even at 10 A g⁻¹. The composite shows no significant morphology changes after 200 cycles, with SnS2 nanoparticles reverting to their original phase without agglomeration, indicating that it is a promising candidate for lithium/sodium storage due to its high rate capabilities and excellent cycle stability.

We present the creation of three-dimensional flower-like MoS2 nanosheet arrays on carbon cloth, serving as a binder-free anode for sodium-ion batteries. These MoS2 surfaces are modified using ultrathin and conformal TiO2 layers applied through atomic layer deposition. Electrochemical performance assessments reveal that the TiO2 layer deposited via ALD enhances the cycling stability and rate capability of MoS2. Our findings show that the MoS2 nanosheets with a 0.5-nm TiO2 coating boast an initial discharge capacity of 1392 mA h g-1 at 200 mA g-1, marking a 53% increase over bare MoS2. After 150 cycles, the TiO2-coated MoS2 maintains 75.8% of its second cycle capacity at 200 mA g-1, compared to 59% for uncoated MoS2. Additionally, the underlying mechanism is elucidated through ex situ SEM, XRD, and EIS characterizations, confirming that the ultrathin TiO2 coatings help impede structural degradation and SEI film formation on the MoS2 electrode.

Authors: Qu, Baihua; Ma, Chuze; Ji, Ge; Xu, Chaohe; Xu, Jing; Meng, Ying Shirley; Wang, Taihong; Lee, Jim Yang | Abstract: A SnS2-reduced graphene oxide (SnS2-RGO) composite with a layered structure has been synthesized using a straightforward hydrothermal method and assessed as an anode material for sodium-ion batteries (NIBs). The composite exhibits excellent electrochemical properties, including a high charge specific capacity of 630 mAh g-1 at 0.2 A g-1, impressive rate performance of 544 mAh g-1 at 2 A g-1, and a substantial cycle life of 500 mAh g-1 at 1 A g-1 over 400 cycles. © 2014 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.

Pyrite (FeS2) is regarded as a highly promising anode material for sodium ion batteries (SIBs) due to its cost-effectiveness, eco-friendliness, and high theoretical capacity. Despite these advantages, its substantial volume changes during charging/discharging and poor conductivity pose challenges for its practical use. In this study, we introduce an easy and scalable technique to fabricate nanostructured FeS2 within an N-doped carbon nanosheet composite (FeS2/CNS) through a combination of template and solid-state sulfuration methods. N-doped carbon nanosheets are expected to mitigate volume changes and improve electrode conductivity. Additionally, the nanoscale particle size, averaging 50-80 nm in diameter, can reduce ion-diffusion paths during sodiation/desodiation processes. Consequently, the FeS2/CNS electrode exhibits a high specific capacity of 812 mA h g-1 at 0.1 A g-1, a prolonged cycling life with 77.2% capacity retention after 350 cycles at 1 A g-1, and remarkable rate capability of 400 mA h g-1 at 5 A g-1 when tested as an SIB anode material. The findings highlight the potential of FeS2/CNS for SIB applications characterized by low cost, high power density, and long cycling life.

Cellulose, valued for its abundance, renewability, and low cost, stands out as an attractive natural bio-macromolecule. In this study, we introduce an innovative approach to create pre-sodiated carbonaceous anodes for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) using cellulose nanofibers (CNFs) and microwave irradiation, aiming for rapid and large-scale production. Typically, direct carbonization of CNFs via microwave methods is challenging due to insufficient microwave absorption. However, we discovered that a small amount of reduced graphene oxide (rGO) can serve as a potent initiator. The microwaving of rGO releases substantial energy, creating localized ultrahigh temperatures and a rapid heating rate, which swiftly carbonizes CNFs and generates pre-sodiated carbonaceous materials in mere seconds. The sodium embedded in these carbonaceous materials, derived from CNFs with sodium-ion carboxyl groups, facilitates effective sodiation/desodiation, thereby enhancing the electrochemical performance of the anode. Employing this microwaved rGO-CNF (MrGO-CNF) as an anode in SIBs yields an impressive initial capacity of 558 mAh g-1, with a retained capacity of 340 mAh g-1 after 200 cycles. This notable reversible capacity and cycling stability highlight the promise of MrGO-CNF as an anode for sodium-ion batteries.

Ensuring structural stability is a significant challenge for high-capacity conversion electrodes that experience substantial volume changes, yet it is crucial for advancing high-energy-density, long-lasting batteries. In this study, we present a stable phosphorus anode for sodium ion batteries achieved via the combined use of a chemically bonded phosphorus-carbon nanotube (P-CNT) hybrid and a cross-linked polymer binder. The P-CNT hybrid was created by ball-milling red phosphorus with carbon nanotubes functionalized with carboxylic groups. The formation of P-O-C bonds in this process maintains the connection between phosphorus and CNTs, resulting in a durable hybrid material. Moreover, a robust electrode was developed using a cross-linked carboxymethyl cellulose-citric acid binder. Consequently, this anode provides a consistent cycling capacity of 1586.2 mAh/g after 100 cycles, with a high initial Coulombic efficiency of 84.7% and a subsequent cycling efficiency of approximately 99%. The unique electrode structure developed through this chemical bonding strategy holds promise for application in other electrode materials that undergo significant volume changes.

Hard carbon (HC) serves as a promising anode material for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) due to its low cost and high energy density. However, its practical application is limited by a low initial coulombic efficiency (ICE). To address this issue, we introduced a straightforward strategy to mitigate the irreversible capacity loss of HC anodes via a chemical presodiation reaction using a sodiation reagent (sodium biphenyl, Na-Bp). Thanks to Na-Bp's strong sodiation capability, the HC anode can be rapidly presodiated in a short duration, achieving a presodiated HC (NaxHC) with an ICE of 100%. When paired with a Na3V2(PO4)3 cathode in a SIB full cell, the NaxHC||Na3V2(PO4)3 cell demonstrates a high ICE of approximately 95.0% and a significantly increased energy density of 218 Wh kg-1, outperforming the control cell with a pristine HC anode (50% ICE and 120 Wh kg-1). This indicates substantial advantages gained from the chemical presodiation process. Importantly, the presodiation reaction is mild, highly efficient, and can be broadly applied to various Na-storage materials, offering a novel approach for developing high-performance Na-storage materials for practical battery applications.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are emerging as a leading alternative to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) for large-scale renewable energy storage, attributed to their cost-effectiveness and the widespread availability of sodium in the earth's mineral deposits. Despite this, research into anode materials for SIBs has predominantly focused on carbon-based materials, with limited attention given to high-capacity alloy-based materials. In this research, we developed an antimony (Sb)/carbon (C) electrode where ~30 nm Sb nanoparticles (NPs) are evenly distributed in interconnected one-dimensional (1D) 400 nm carbon fibers, referred to as SbNP@C. This electrode was produced via a straightforward and scalable electrospinning technique, without needing a binder or current collector. The SbNP@C electrode exhibited high capacity and stable performance over extensive cycling at various current densities. Initially, it achieved a total capacity of 422 mAh/gelectrode, maintaining 350 mAh/gelectrode after 300 deep charge-discharge cycles at 100 mA/gSb. Furthermore, due to the effective 1D sodium-ion transport pathway and the conductive network of SbNP@C, the electrode maintained high capacities even at elevated currents, making it suitable for high power applications.

The advancement of viable, scalable, and eco-friendly electrode materials that provide consistent cycling performance is essential for the success of post-lithium rechargeable batteries and supercapacitors. Focusing on sodium-ion battery (SIB) anodes made from transition metal dichalcogenides like molybdenum disulfide (MoS2), issues such as inadequate cycle stability and rapid capacity loss—caused by low electronic conductivity and dissolution of chemical species in the electrolyte—impede the use of these promising layered materials as SIB anodes. In this study, we present the chemical functionalization of MoS2 nanosheets with polymer-derived silicon oxycarbide (SiOC) to protect MoS2 from dissolving in the SIB organic electrolyte, while maintaining its function during sodiation and desodiation. Our findings indicate that a MoS2–SiOC composite electrode significantly enhances cycle stability in sodium-ion cycling compared to pure MoS2, even after 100 cycles.

Hard carbon is viewed as the leading anode option for room temperature sodium ion batteries, given its relatively high capacity, affordability, and good scalability. This study involves the carbonization of switchgrass, a type of biomass, at an extremely high temperature of 2050 °C using Joule heating, to develop hard carbon anodes for sodium ion batteries. The carbon materials derived from switchgrass naturally retain its three-dimensional porous hierarchical structure, featuring an average interlayer spacing of 0.376 nm. This larger interlayer spacing compared to graphite facilitates substantial Na ion storage performance. In comparison to carbonized samples at 1000 °C, the switchgrass derived carbon processed at 2050 °C exhibits enhanced initial Coulombic efficiency. Furthermore, the unique high-temperature treatment results in exceptional rate capability and outstanding cycling performance for the switchgrass derived carbon.

To advance sodium ion battery technology, understanding the mechanisms related to their reversibility is crucial for the innovative design of electrode structures. In this study, we employ a hydrogel-embedding technique to limit the development of few-layer SnS2 nanosheets between nitrogen- and sulfur-doped carbon nanotubes (NS-CNT) and amorphous carbon. These carbon-layered SnS2 nanosheets exhibit exceptional sodium storage capabilities. Through operando small angle X-ray scattering and ex situ X-ray absorption near-edge spectra, we observe that the redox reactions between SnS2/NS-CNT and sodium ions are highly reversible. However, the evolution of the nanostructure is irreversible, as the SnS2 nanosheets disintegrate and convert into SnS2 nanoparticles. This research provides operando insights into the chemical environment and structural changes of SnS2-based anodes, clarifying their reversible reaction mechanisms and highlighting the importance of designed carbon supports in maintaining the stability of electrode structures.

We conducted a thorough examination of single-layer VS2 polytypes as potential anode materials for sodium-ion batteries using density functional theory calculations. Our findings indicate that sodiation tends to prevent the 1H-to-1T structural phase transition, unlike the transition caused by lithiation in monolayer MoS2, suggesting that VS2 could offer enhanced structural stability during charge-discharge cycles. Sodium atom diffusion on both polytypes is notably rapid, exhibiting minimal diffusion barriers of 0.085 eV for 1H and 0.088 eV for 1T. To identify stable configurations of Na on VS2, we used ab initio random structure searching, which showed that the V top and hexagonal center sites are the preferred adsorption sites for Na, with the 1H phase demonstrating stronger binding. Remarkably, our search discovered that Na can form clusters as a stacked second layer at full concentration, a finding not reported previously where single-layer uniform Na adsorption was assumed. With reasonably high specific energy capacities (232.91 mAh/g for 1H and 116.45 mAh/g for 1T) and open-circuit voltages (1.30 V for 1H and 1.42 V for 1T), VS2 stands out as a promising candidate for Na-ion battery anodes due to its excellent structural durability. Furthermore, we demonstrated the effectiveness of ab initio random structure searching for evaluating potential materials in energy storage applications.

A vanadium oxide nanofilm-coated graphene oxide (GO) was developed through the thermally induced explosive disintegration of a microcrystalline ammonium peroxovanadate-GO composite. The GO sheets serve to isolate the microcrystalline grains and trap the microexplosion products, facilitating the deposition of nanoscale materials onto the GO. Thermal treatment of this supported nanofilm results in a series of nanocrystalline vanadium oxide phases (V3O7, VO2), depending on the temperature. This method represents the first instance of using microexplosive disintegration of a crystalline peroxo compound to create a nanocoating. Given the abundance of recently reported peroxide-rich crystalline materials, this technique presents a potentially valuable general method for nanofilm formation. Testing of the V3O7@GO composite as a sodium ion battery anode revealed a high charge capacity during high rate charge-discharge cycles (150 mAh g-1 at 3000 mA g-1 compared to 300 mAh g-1 at 100 mA g-1), attributable to the nanomorphology of the vanadium oxide.

Tin disulfide (SnS2) is gaining attention as a promising anode material for sodium ion batteries (NIBs) because of its distinctive layered structure, high theoretical capacity, and affordability. Typically, SnS2 nanomaterials are synthesized via the hydrothermal method, which is both time-intensive and challenging to scale for large production. In this research, we introduce a straightforward solid-state reaction technique to synthesize carbon-coated SnS2 (SnS2/C) anode materials by annealing metallic Sn, sulfur powder, and polyacrylonitrile in a sealed vacuum glass tube. The resulting SnS2/C nanospheres, characterized by their unique layered structure, demonstrate a high reversible capacity of 660 mAh g(-1) at a current density of 50 mA g(-1) and sustain 570 mAh g(-1) over 100 cycles with a degradation rate of 0.14% per cycle. This represents one of the best cycling performances among reported SnS2/C anodes for NIBs so far. The excellent cycling stability of the SnS2/C electrode is linked to the stable nanosphere morphology and its structural integrity throughout the charge/discharge cycles, as shown by ex situ characterization.

The abstract for this paper cannot be directly accessed from the provided information, as it only includes author details and contact information. If you provide the actual abstract text, I can assist with the rephrasing.

Sodium resources are cost-effective and plentiful, making sodium-ion batteries a promising substitute for lithium-ion batteries. Nevertheless, their lower energy density and poor cycling stability hinder the practical application of current sodium-ion batteries for future smart power grids and stationary storage systems. Tin oxides (SnO2) present a potential high-capacity anode material for future sodium-ion batteries, benefiting from high sodium storage capacity, significant abundance, and low toxicity. Despite this, SnO2-based anodes remain unsuitable for practical use due to substantial volume changes during repeated charge and discharge cycles. These volume changes cause severe pulverization of the active material and disrupt the electrical contact between the SnO2 and the carbon conductor, leading to a rapid loss of capacity during cycling. In this study, we present a novel amorphous carbon-coated SnO2-electrodeposited porous carbon nanofiber (PCNF@SnO2@C) composite, which not only offers high sodium storage ability but also preserves its structural integrity through ongoing repetitive cycles. Electrochemical evaluations show that this SnO2-incorporating nanofiber composite anode exhibits outstanding electrochemical performance, including high capacity (374 mAh g^(-1)), robust capacity retention (82.7%), and significant Coulombic efficiency (98.9% after 100 cycles).

Sodium ion batteries (SIBs) are increasingly considered a leading option for large-scale energy storage, with the development of high-performance anode materials being a key challenge for their advancement. Innovative Sn-MoS2-C@C microspheres have been synthesized using the hydrothermal method, where Sn nanoparticles are uniformly incorporated into MoS2 nanosheets and covered with a uniform thin carbon film. These microspheres exhibit exceptional Na-storage capabilities as anodes for SIBs, achieving a high reversible charge capacity of 580.3 mAh g⁻¹ at 0.05 A g⁻¹ and impressive rate capacities of 580.3, 373, 326, 285.2, and 181.9 mAh g⁻¹ at 0.05, 0.5, 1, 2, and 5 A g⁻¹, respectively. Even after 2750 cycles at 2 A g⁻¹, a substantial charge specific capacity of 245 mAh g⁻¹ is maintained, demonstrating excellent cycling stability. The combination of high capacity and long-term durability positions the Sn-MoS2-C@C composite as a promising anode material for SIBs.

Red phosphorus (P) is considered a highly promising anode material for high-energy density sodium-ion batteries (NIBs) due to its significant sodium storage theoretical capacity of 2595 mAh g−1. However, its inherent insulating nature and significant volume changes during cycling cause very low electrochemical activity, resulting in subpar electrochemical performance. This study presents an effective approach to enhance the sodium storage capabilities of red P by confining nanosized amorphous red P within a zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8) derived nitrogen-doped microporous carbon matrix, referred to as P@N-MPC. As an NIB anode, the P@N-MPC composite achieves a high reversible specific capacity of approximately 600 mAh g−1 at 0.15 A g−1 and an improved rate capacity of about 450 mAh g−1 at 1 A g−1 after 1000 cycles, with an exceptionally low capacity fading rate of 0.02% per cycle. The outstanding sodium storage performance of P@N-MPC is primarily attributed to its innovative structure. The N-doped porous carbon with sub-1 nm micropores facilitates quick diffusion of organic electrolyte ions and enhances the conductivity of the embedded red P. Additionally, the porous carbon matrix cushions the volume fluctuations of red P during repeated sodiation/desodiation, maintaining structural integrity over extended cycling.

The dual-ion battery (DIB) system is gaining significant attention due to its advantages, such as low cost, high energy capacity, and eco-friendliness. Nevertheless, DIBs utilizing sodium-ion electrolytes are rarely explored, primarily because of the scarcity of suitable anode materials for reversible Na+ insertion and extraction. In this study, we introduce a novel sodium-ion based DIB, called MoS2/C-G DIB, which employs a penne-like MoS2/C nanotube as the anode and expanded graphite as the cathode. This is the first time such a system has been constructed and optimized. The hierarchical structure of the MoS2/C nanotube offers an expanded (002) interlayer spacing within 2H-MoS2, enhancing the kinetics of the Na+ insertion and extraction reactions and thereby improving the DIB's performance. The MoS2/C-G DIB achieves a reversible capacity of 65 mAh g⁻¹ at 2 C within a voltage range of 1.0-4.0 V, maintaining good cycling stability over 200 cycles with 85% capacity retention. This demonstrates the viability of sodium-ion based DIBs for potential applications.

Incorporating functional nanostructures into a lightweight nanocarbon framework holds significant promise for creating advanced electrodes with superior performance in rechargeable batteries. In this study, core-shell (FeSe2/C) nanostructures are integrated into a carbon nanotube (CNT) framework through a simple wet-chemistry technique, followed by thermal selenization, to achieve practical capacity. The CNT framework provides 3D continuous pathways for electronic and ionic transfer, while macropores offer ample space to accommodate high mass loading of FeSe2/C. The carbon shell not only establishes a solid electronic connection between CNTs and FeSe2 but also enhances the diffusivity of sodium ions into FeSe2 and serves as a buffer to manage volume changes. The distinctive structural properties of CNT/FeSe2/C make it an excellent host for sodium storage, with a capacity retention of 546 mAh g-1 even after 100 cycles at 100 mA g-1. Furthermore, it achieves areal and volumetric capacities of 5.06 mAh cm-2 and 158 mAh cm-3 at a high mass loading of 16.9 mg cm-2. The exceptional performance attributed to this multi-functional engineered structure suggests its potential as a candidate for secondary ion batteries, and its straightforward synthesis could be extended to fabricate more complex structures with other morphologies, such as nanorods and nanowires, to satisfy high energy requirements.

In this paper, we present NiSe2 nanooctahedra as a promising anode material for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). These nanooctahedra demonstrate exceptional long-term cyclic stability, maintaining 313 mAh/g after 4000 cycles at a rate of 5 A/g, and exhibit excellent high-rate performance with 175 mAh/g at 20 A/g. Additionally, the initial Coulombic efficiency of NiSe2 is notably high, exceeding 90%. These outstanding results are due to NiSe2's good conductivity, structural stability, and pseudocapacitive behavior. Furthermore, the sodium ion storage mechanism in NiSe2 is explored using in situ and ex situ XRD techniques. These findings position NiSe2 as a strong candidate for rechargeable SIBs.

The development of electrode materials for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) that are affordable, long-lasting, and capable of high-rate performance is crucial. Nonetheless, most SIB electrodes face the challenge of slow sodiation kinetics, hindering fast charging and high power density. In this study, we synthesized uniform and mesoporous NiS2 nanospheres through a simple polyvinylpyrrolidone-assisted one-step method. By optimizing the voltage window, these mesoporous NiS2 nanospheres demonstrate commendable electrochemical performance in SIBs, providing a high reversible specific capacity of 692 mA h g-1. The NiS2 anode shows remarkable high-rate capability (253 mA h g-1 at 5 A g-1) and sustained cycling performance (maintaining 319 mA h g-1 after 1000 cycles at 0.5 A g-1). A significant pseudocapacitance contribution is confirmed through kinetics analysis. Furthermore, the electrochemical processes involving amorphization and conversion reactions of the mesoporous NiS2 nanospheres are examined via in situ X-ray diffraction. The outstanding electrochemical performance indicates that NiS2 is highly promising for advancing next-generation large-scale energy storage systems.

Liquid plasma generated by nanosecond pulses offers an efficient and straightforward method for creating a nanocomposite structure of Co3O4/CNTs using carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and Co3O4 nanoparticle clusters in deionized water. A key aspect of this composite's design is the uniform dispersion and anchoring of Co3O4 nanoparticle clusters to the CNT networks, where Co3O4 ensures high electrochemical reactivity with sodium, and CNTs provide conductivity and structural stability for the anode. Our findings show that the Co3O4/CNT nanocomposite achieves a stable and high capacity of 403 mA h g(-1) at 50 mA g(-1) after 100 cycles, with sodium uptake and extraction confirmed via a reversible conversion reaction using ex situ techniques. The composite's rate capability is markedly enhanced, showing a reversible capacity of 212 mA h g(-1) at 1.6 A g(-1) and 190 mA h g(-1) at 3.2 A g(-1). The straightforward synthesis process coupled with impressive electrochemical performance makes Co3O4/CNT nanocomposites promising candidates as anode materials for sodium-ion batteries.

We present the development of an advanced sodium-based dual-ion battery (Na-DIB) that integrates the benefits of dual-ion batteries (DIBs) and sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). This battery utilizes a PTCDA organic anode paired with an ionic liquid (IL) electrolyte. It achieves a peak specific discharge capacity of 177 mAh g-1 at a 0.5C rate and demonstrates outstanding capacity retention, exceeding 100% at 2C after 200 cycles. Remarkably, at an extremely high rate of 20C, the battery sustains a significant capacity of 60 mAh g-1, maintaining nearly 100% coulombic efficiency and 94% capacity retention after 1000 cycles. Additionally, the system exhibits a very low self-discharge rate of 0.18% per hour. Thus, this study introduces an exceptional Na-DIB system that holds great potential for large-scale applications.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are promising candidates for grid-scale energy storage systems but must be capable of operating under extreme weather conditions. Despite this need, there have been few reports on SIBs that function across a wide temperature range. In this study, we introduce a wide-temperature SIB featuring a carbon-coated Na4Fe3(PO4)2P2O7 (NFPP@C) cathode, a Bismuth (Bi) anode, and a diglyme-based electrolyte. We demonstrate that the Bi anode can directly store solvated Na+ through an alloying reaction without needing a de-solvent process. Additionally, the NFPP@C cathode shows a high Na+ diffusion coefficient at low temperatures. Consequently, the Bi//NFPP@C battery performs exceptionally well at low temperatures, retaining 70.19% of its room-temperature capacity even at -70 °C. Moreover, due to the high boiling point of the electrolyte, the battery operates effectively at temperatures up to 100 °C. These promising results may illuminate the path toward developing wide-temperature SIBs.

Ultrafine niobium oxide nanocrystals with reduced graphene oxide (Nb2O5 NCs/rGO) have been shown to be a promising anode material for sodium ion batteries, offering excellent rate capability and long-lasting cycling stability. This composite was created through the controlled hydrolysis of niobium ethoxide, followed by a heat treatment at 450 °C in a flowing forming gas atmosphere. Transmission electron microscopy revealed that Nb2O5 NCs, with an average size of 3 nm, were evenly distributed on rGO sheets, with voids present between the nanocrystals. This structure, with ultrafine Nb2O5 NCs anchored on a conductive rGO network, not only improves charge transfer and buffers volume changes during the sodiation/desodiation process but also increases the active surface area for sodium ion storage, leading to enhanced rate capability and cycling performance. Ex situ XPS analyses indicated that sodium ion storage in Nb2O5 might involve a Nb(5+)/Nb(4+) redox reaction, with the ultrafine Nb2O5 NCs providing additional surface area for this redox process.

For the first time, MnO2 is demonstrated to be electrochemically active as a conversion anode in Na-ion batteries (NIBs). Ultrafine (UF)-MnO2 with an average crystal size of 4 nm, produced via a porous silicon dioxide templated hydrothermal method, shows a high reversible sodiation capacity of 567 mA h g(-1). This is in stark contrast to the negligible activity observed with larger (14 nm) MnO2 nanocrystallite aggregates. The enhanced sodiation performance of UF-MnO2 is due to its significantly smaller crystal size, which aids Na ion diffusion, and its high surface energy from extensive heterogeneous interfacial bonding with the surrounding SiO2. The UF-MnO2 anode also demonstrates exceptional rate and cycle stability, with over 70% capacity retention after 500 cycles. In operando synchrotron X-ray absorption near-edge structural analysis identifies combined charge-storage mechanisms involving a conversion reaction between Mn(III) and Mn(II) oxides, Mn(III)-O1.5 + Na(+) + e(-) ↔ 1/2Na2O + Mn(II)-O, as well as non-Mn-centered redox reactions. This discovery proposes a new strategy for "activating" potential electrochemical electrode materials that appear inactive in their bulk form.

Current lithium-ion batteries encounter issues related to sustainability, cost, and the availability of raw materials. Sodium presents an alternative energy storage option, offering substantial volumetric energy density. In developing sodium ion batteries (SIBs), hard carbon replaces graphite at the anode due to its micro domain structure conducive to sodium ion storage. Coal char, an economical source of hard carbon, emerges as a promising candidate. Utilizing coal char in SIBs not only offers an efficient reuse of coal's abundant char component but also adds value.

This research investigates flash pyrolyzation as an innovative method for producing coal char suitable for SIB anodes, using bituminous coal sourced from Utah. Flash pyrolyzation involves heating char in a drop-tube furnace at a rapid rate of 1000 °C/s, contrasting with conventional slow pyrolyzation which heats at 20 °C/min. The flash pyrolyzed (FP) char displays a significantly different surface structure than slow pyrolyzed (SP) char, including a larger d-spacing (FP: 0.379 nm; SP: 0.364 nm) and a smaller closed micropore diameter (FP: 1.52 nm; SP: 1.91 nm), as revealed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and small angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) analyses.

The performance of FP char versus SP char as SIB anodes is evaluated in both ether-based and ester-based electrolytes. FP char demonstrates superior performance as an anode in both electrolyte types. Notably, both char anodes show improved reversible capacity and initial coulombic efficiencies (ICE) in ether-based electrolytes compared to ester-based ones. Notably, FP char combined with ether-based electrolytes achieves a 10th cycle reversible capacity of 109.4 mAh/g, whereas SP char with an ester-based electrolyte maintains a capacity of 72.5 mAh/g, with cells cycled at 50 mA/g (sodium metal half-cells). Additionally, FP ether cells reach an ICE of 64%, whereas SP ester cells exhibit an ICE of 52%. The enhanced electrochemical performance of FP cells is attributed to surface and bulk structure differences resulting from the rapid heating rate. The improvement seen with ether-based cells may be linked to the formation of a thinner solid-electrolyte interphase or better sodiation facilitated by the ether-based electrolyte.

Sodium ion batteries (SIBs) have regained attention as a viable alternative to lithium ion batteries due to sodium's affordability, abundance, and comparable storage mechanism. Among potential materials, VS4 stands out as a cost-effective anode for SIBs thanks to its unique linear chains capable of accommodating sodium. In this work, we explore the use of VS4 grown on reduced graphene oxide (rGO) as an anode for SIBs for the first time. The resulting VS4/rGO anode demonstrates encouraging performance, achieving a reversible capacity of 362 mAh g(-1) at a current density of 100 mA g(-1), along with a commendable rate performance. We delve into the sodium storage characteristics of the VS4/rGO composite. Unlike most transition metal sulfides, this composite undergoes a distinct three-step separation during sodiation (transitioning from VS4 to metallic V and Na2S, with an electrochemical behavior similar to Na-S). Thus, the VS4/rGO composite emerges as a promising material for rechargeable SIBs.

The urgent need for intrinsically safe sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) with long lifespans for large-scale energy storage is addressed in this work. Currently, many developed SIBs are limited by a short cycle life and safety concerns. We present an all-phosphate sodium-ion battery (AP-SIB) composed of a Na3V2(PO4)3 cathode, a NaTi2(PO4)3 anode, and a nonflammable trimethyl phosphate (TMP) electrolyte. This AP-SIB demonstrates impressive safety features, superior rate performance, and exceptionally long cycle life. Its zero-strain properties, attributed to the inverse volume change of the phosphate materials during charging and discharging, provide a safer and more cycle-stable solution for Na-ion technology in electric storage applications.

Designing anode materials for sodium-ion batteries remains challenging. Although alloy anodes offer high gravimetric and volumetric capacities, they often experience short cycle lives due to the continuous pulverization caused by significant volume changes during cycling. In this study, with pure Sn, an irreversible conversion reaction combined with an alloy reaction (SnO), and a reversible conversion reaction combined with an alloy reaction (Sn4P3) as examples, we illustrate that pulverization and aggregation in alloy anodes can be partially reversed, and their further development during charge/discharge cycles can be halted with a reversible conversion reaction combined with an alloy reaction. The cycling stability of these three Sn-based anodes improves in the order of Sn4P3 > SnO > Sn. The improvements in Sn4P3 are attributed to the reversible reaction Sn4P3 + 9Na ↔ 4Sn + 3Na3P, which mends the cracks, damage, and aggregation of Sn particles occurring in the alloy process 4Sn + 15Na ↔ Na15Sn4 during cycling, thus stopping pulverization. This repair mechanism mirrors nature's self-healing ability, where damage repairs itself, justifying the term "self-healing anode." Employing self-healing strategies to construct electrode architecture is innovative and highly beneficial as it extends cycle life and provides a general strategy for creating stable electrode materials.

Potassium-ion batteries (PIBs) are promising alternatives to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) due to the abundance and low cost of potassium. In our study, we explored Sn4P3/C composite as a new anode material for PIBs. This electrode showed a reversible capacity of 384.8 mA h g^-1 at 50 mA g^-1 and an impressive rate capability of 221.9 mA h g^-1, even at 1 A g^-1, outperforming any other anode material reported for PIBs to date. Additionally, the Sn4P3/C electrode exhibited a discharge potential plateau of 0.1 V in PIBs, slightly higher than that in sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) (0.01 V) and significantly higher than the metal plating potential. This characteristic helps to reduce dendrite formation during cycling, making Sn4P3 a relatively safe anode option, particularly for large-scale energy storage applications where substantial quantities of electrode materials are utilized. Furthermore, we proposed a possible reaction mechanism for the Sn4P3/C composite as a PIB anode. This research could pave the way for the advancement of alloy-based anodes with high capacity and extended cycle life for PIBs.

Single-layered MoS2 holds promise as an anode material for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), and potassium-ion batteries (PIBs) because of its high capacity and isotropic ion transport pathways. However, its application is limited by its low intrinsic conductivity and tendency to agglomerate. This study proposes a charge-driven interlayer expansion strategy where Co2+ ions replace Mo4+ ions through doping, giving the MoS2 layers negative charges that induce electrostatic repulsion. This, combined with the inclusion of gaseous groups, leads to interlayer expansion by overcoming van der Waals forces, yielding single-layered MoS2 uniformly dispersed in a carbon matrix. This dispersion results from the transformation of carbonaceous gaseous groups under high vapor pressure. Doping with Co atoms increases the intrinsic conductivity of the single-layered MoS2, while the carbon matrix effectively prevents its agglomeration. These Co atoms can be entirely converted into ultra-small Co nanoparticles during conversion reactions, which enhance spin-polarized surface capacitance, significantly improving ion transport and storage. As a result, this material expresses excellent Li/Na/K-ion storage performance, surpassing other reported MoS2-based anodes. The charge-driven interlayer expansion strategy offers a new approach for preparing single-layered MoS2, showing significant promise for energy storage applications.

Carbon-coated TiO2 microsphere electrodes, produced via a hydrothermal approach, were developed for sodium ion batteries and assessed for their electrochemical characteristics based on varying carbon content. The carbon layer, applied by adding sucrose, effectively inhibited the enlargement of TiO2 primary crystallites during the calcination process. The TiO2 electrodes with a 20 wt % sucrose carbon coating demonstrated exceptional cycle stability over 50 cycles (100% retention) and remarkable rate capability up to a 30 C rate at ambient temperature. This system provided impressive discharge capacities: 155 mAh g(composite)(-1) at 0.1 C, 149 mAh g(composite)(-1) at 1 C, and 82.7 mAh g(composite)(-1) at a 10 C rate.

A three-dimensional spider-web structure composed of Na2Ti3O7 nanotubes has been developed through a hydrothermal synthesis process. For the first time, this self-similar network architecture demonstrates outstanding performance as an anode in a room-temperature sodium ion battery, operating effectively without the need for any additives such as binders or conducting agents.

Despite the long-standing dominance of lithium-ion battery (LIB) technology, rising demand and the increasing cost of lithium resources are driving the swift development of alternative energy storage solutions. Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), offering similar electrochemical properties at a lower cost, have attracted considerable research interest. However, significant challenges remain due to the larger ionic radius of sodium ions, leading to lower reversible capacity and shorter lifespan. To address these issues, enhancing anode materials has shown to be an effective strategy. This paper reviews the latest research on promising anode materials for SIBs and explores future prospects in this area.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are promising for large-scale energy storage, yet their power density is often restricted by slow Na+ diffusion in cathode and anode materials. In this study, the authors present an ultrahigh power SIB prototype that uses a high-rate Na3V2(PO4)3 (NVP) cathode, a graphite-type mesocarbon microbeads (MCMB) anode, and a Na+-diglyme electrolyte. The NVP cathode's overpotential adheres to Ohm's law. The NVP@C@carbon nanotubes (CNTs) cathode, featuring high-conductivity CNT networks, demonstrates excellent electronic conductivity, minimizing overpotential and charge transfer resistance, and achieves a significant rate capability over 1000C. For the MCMB anode, the initial [Na-diglyme]+ co-intercalation is largely pseudocapacitive, with expanded graphite layers facilitating rapid ion diffusion subsequently. The cathode and anode exhibit well-matched rapid (de)intercalation kinetics. As a result, the assembled MCMB|1 m NaPF6 in diglyme|NVP@C@CNTs full-cell SIB achieves an energy density of 88 Wh kg−1 at a high power density of about 10 kW kg−1, and an energy density of 58 Wh kg−1 even at an ultrahigh power density of 23 kW kg−1. These promising outcomes highlight the potential of high-power SIBs for future large-scale applications.

The behavior at the anode/electrolyte interface, and consequently the overall performance of sodium-ion batteries, is dictated by a complex interplay of processes occurring across all components of the electrochemical cell on diverse size and time scales. Studies focusing on a single scale may not provide a complete understanding, as they fail to capture the full complexity of this interconnected behavior. Therefore, comprehensive, multiscale studies are crucial for clarifying these processes. This perspectives article introduces various analytical and theoretical techniques and explains how their integration can lead to a more thorough understanding of sodium-ion battery (SIB) performance over its lifespan, particularly emphasizing the interfaces of hard carbon anodes. The methods introduced target different length and time scales, from micro to nano, and from the cell level to atomic structures, covering a wide range of physical and (electro)chemical properties. The article explores how techniques such as mass spectrometry, microscopy, spectroscopy, electrochemical analysis, thermodynamics, and physical methods can be applied to acquire the different types of information needed to comprehend battery behavior. It also discusses how combining these techniques can elucidate the multiscale phenomena at the anode interface, thereby contributing to a comprehensive understanding of their impact on the overall function of sodium-ion batteries.

Designing 3D graphene/metal composites with very small metal sizes and strong metal–graphene interfacial connections for energy storage remains difficult and seldom documented. This study presents a simple top-down approach to create SnSb-in-plane nanoconfined 3D N-doped porous graphene networks for sodium-ion battery anodes. These networks consist of multiple interconnected empty N-graphene boxes with ultrasmall SnSb nanocrystals embedded firmly in-plane. The complete encapsulation architecture (plane-to-plane contact) substantially increases the interface between N-graphene and SnSb nanocrystals, enhancing electron conductivity and maintaining structural integrity of the electrode. Additionally, it provides extra interfacial sodium storage, significantly improving high-rate sodium storage capacity and stability, as demonstrated through experimental results and first-principles simulations. This top-down method also paves the way for low-cost, high-yield production of 3D graphene/metal composites for energy-related applications and other fields.

We present a novel sodium-ion battery created by pairing a NaFePO₄ cathode with a nanocomposite tin-carbon (Sn-C) sodium-alloying anode. The NaFePO₄ cathode is produced through the Li-Na conversion of a LiFePO₄ cathode directly within the complete cell, using the Sn-C anode and a sodium-ion electrolyte. Our findings indicate that this distinctive method effectively converts LiFePO₄ into NaFePO₄ within a sodium-ion battery, operating at a 3 V voltage, achieving a maximum reversible capacity of 150 mAh g⁻¹, with excellent reversibility and high rate capability.

Crystalline Covalent Organic Frameworks (COFs) have structured nano-channels that can be enhanced with redox-active groups to function as anodes in metal ion batteries, specifically LIB and SIB. Despite sodium’s greater availability over lithium, its larger ion size complicates its compatibility with the graphite anodes used in Li-ion batteries due to unfavorable intercalation. Additionally, sodium ions move slowly within electrodes, hampering the rapid sodiation necessary for SIB. By chemically creating an electronic driving force at the electrodes, this hurdle can be addressed. This study introduces SIB anodes utilizing three isostructural COFs with similar Highest Occupied Molecular Orbitals (HOMO) levels but different Lowest Unoccupied Molecular Orbitals (LUMO) energy levels. The LUMO level variation is strategically achieved by inserting electron-deficient (phenyl, tetrazine, or bispyridine-tetrazine) substituents into the COF structures. A decrease in cell potential leads to electron accumulation in the anti-bonding LUMO, enabling these electron-enriched LUMOs to effectively attract the otherwise slow sodium ions from the electrolyte. Furthermore, the COF's inherent porosity supports the accommodation and diffusion of Na+ ions. Cells using these COFs deliver impressive specific capacity (energy density) and rate performance (rapid charging-discharging), which is challenging to achieve with Na+ compared to the smaller Li+ ions. Notably, the bispyridine-tetrazine COF shows a specific capacity of 340 mA h g-1 at 1 A g-1 and 128 mA h g-1 at a high current density of 15 A g-1. There is only a 24% reduction in performance when increasing the current density from 0.1 to 1 A g-1, marking it as the lowest performance drop among leading COF-based Na-ion battery anodes.

Symmetric sodium ion batteries offer advantages like affordability, ease of manufacturing, and simple recycling processes, making them ideal for large-scale stationary energy storage applications. In this study, we introduce a symmetric sodium ion battery that utilizes dual-electron reactions with NASICON structured Na3MnTi(PO4)3. The Na3MnTi(PO4)3 electrode achieves a stable capacity of up to 160 mAh g-1 and a Coulombic efficiency of 97% at 0.1 C through the redox reactions of Ti3+/4+, Mn2+/3+, and Mn3+/4+. This research marks the first investigation of a symmetric sodium-ion full cell using Na3MnTi(PO4)3 as both the cathode and anode in an organic electrolyte, showing excellent reversibility and cycling performance with voltage plateaus at approximately 1.4 V and 1.9 V. The full cell exhibits a reversible capacity of 75 mAh g-1 at 0.1 C and an energy density of 52 Wh kg-1. Additionally, ex-situ XRD analysis and first-principle calculations were used to explore the sodiation mechanism and structural changes. This research offers a viable approach for symmetric sodium-ion batteries to achieve high energy density.

To develop a high-performance anode for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), binary zinc phosphides (ZnP2 and Zn3P2) were synthesized via an easy solid-state heat treatment method, and their ability to store sodium was assessed. ZnP2 displayed superior sodium reactivity compared to Zn3P2. Consequently, a C-modified composite based on ZnP2 (ZnP2-C) was produced to enhance electrochemical performance. To understand the electrochemical reaction mechanism of ZnP2-C during sodiation and desodiation, various ex-situ analytical methods were utilized. During sodiation, ZnP2 in the composite converted into NaZn13 and Na3P phases in a one-step conversion reaction. In contrast, during desodiation, Zn and P in NaZn13 and Na3P fully recombined to form the original ZnP2 phase. Due to the single-step conversion/recombination of ZnP2 in the composite during cycling, ZnP2-C demonstrated superior electrochemical performance with a highly reversible capacity of 883 mAh g-1 after 130 cycles without capacity loss, and a rapid C-rate capability of 500 mAh g-1 at 1C and 350 mAh g-1 at 3C.

Aromatic organic compounds hold potential as electrode materials in rechargeable batteries and are anticipated to drive advancements in both anode and cathode materials for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). However, most aromatic organic compounds tested as anode materials for SIBs so far have shown notable degradation under rapid charge/discharge conditions and have not achieved satisfactory long-term cycling performance. A new molecular design approach is introduced to enhance the stability of organic compounds used in battery electrodes. The compound [2.2.2.2]paracyclophane-1,9,17,25-tetraene (PCT) is designed to stabilize its neutral state through local aromaticity and its doubly reduced state through global aromaticity. This design leads to an anode material with exceptionally stable cycling performance and excellent performance under fast charge/discharge conditions, presenting an innovative direction for the development of electrode materials for SIBs and other battery types.

Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2), a two-dimensional layered compound, is considered a promising anode material for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) because of its attractive theoretical capacity and affordability. However, MoS2 faces challenges such as poor rate capability due to slow Na+ intercalation kinetics and inadequate cycling stability resulting from the stacking of MoS2 sheets. This study introduces a novel bundled defect-rich MoS2 (BD-MoS2) structure, created through a simple quenching process, where MoS2 with large vacancies is bundled by ultrathin MoO3. As an anode for SIBs, the BD-MoS2 electrode demonstrates ultrafast charge/discharge performance, attributed to its pseudocapacitive Na+ storage mechanism. Experimental and theoretical findings reveal that Na+ ions traverse the MoS2 layers via vacancies, not just diffusing along the layers, enabling a 3D Na+ diffusion with enhanced kinetics. Additionally, the bundled architecture minimizes sheet stacking, leading to an improved cycle life, evidenced by highly reversible capacities of 350 and 272 mAh g-1 at 2 and 5 A g-1, respectively, after 1000 cycles.

Hard carbon (HC) is considered the leading choice for sodium-ion battery anode materials. Various characteristics, such as the intensity ratio of the Raman spectrum, the lateral size of HC crystallite (La), and the interlayer distance (d002), have been evaluated for their impact on anode performance. However, these characteristics do not directly pertain to the bulk properties of the Na+ intercalation reaction, as Raman analysis is highly sensitive to surfaces and La and d002 provide merely one-dimensional crystalline data. In this study, it is proposed that the crystallite interlayer area (Ai), determined using La, d002, and stacking height (Lc), is crucial for governing Na+ intercalation behavior in different HCs. It was found that a range of wood-derived HCs exhibited similar total capacities of around 250 mAh g-1, while the Na+ intercalation capacity (Ci) was proportional to Ai, with a correlation coefficient of R2 = 0.94. The Ai evaluation factor was also applicable to past studies and showed a strong correlation with their Ci, suggesting that Ai is more broadly applicable than traditional evaluation methods.

The use of a polyacrylic acid (PAA)-carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC) binder has been shown to improve the performance of oxide-based anodes in batteries. A range of oxide powders has been produced, exhibiting exceptionally high capacity and cycling stability, achievements seldom reached prior, notably without the need for special carbon modifications or precise control of morphology.

Sodium's abundant availability makes sodium-ion rechargeable batteries a favorable alternative to lithium-ion batteries for large-scale energy storage, as long as a suitable host cathode is found that meets the necessary requirements for capacity, voltage, and cycle life at specific charge/discharge rates. Hexacyanometallates present an attractive option as cathodes due to their low cost, ease of production, and stable open framework that supports rapid Na(+) insertion and removal. This study reveals the interesting impact of interstitial H2O on the structure and electrochemical behavior of sodium manganese(II) hexacyanoferrates(II) with the composition Na2MnFe(CN)6·zH2O (Na2-δMnHFC). The newly identified dehydrated Na2-δMnHFC phase demonstrates remarkable electrochemical performance, surpassing other known Na-ion cathode materials. It achieves a reversible capacity of 150 mAh g(-1) at 3.5 V in a sodium half cell and 140 mAh g(-1) in a full cell with a hard-carbon anode. At a discharge rate of 20 C, the half-cell capacity reaches 120 mAh g(-1), and at a rate of 0.7 C, the cell retains 75% of its capacity after 500 cycles.

Graphene-based nanomaterials have emerged as promising candidates for anode materials in sodium-ion batteries, driven by the exceptional properties of graphene and the synergistic interaction between graphene and active materials. Nonetheless, the 2D nature of graphene primarily facilitates rapid sodium ion diffusion along parallel directions, while vertical diffusion remains challenging, thus constraining the rate capability of graphene-based electrodes. To address this issue, a pore-forming technique is utilized to puncture graphene, simultaneously enabling the in situ growth of Co3Se4 nanoparticles. The creation of in-plane nanoholes disrupts the physical barriers of graphene nanosheets, promoting quick diffusion of electrolyte ions vertically. Furthermore, this strategy curtails the aggregation of Co3Se4 nanoparticles due to Co3Se4’s strong affinity for graphene. With enhanced conductivity and accelerated ion transport provided by this innovative design, the Co3Se4/holey graphene manifests a notable rate performance of 519.5 mAh g−1 at 5.0 A g−1 along with commendable cycle stability. The study concludes that sodium transport within graphene-based composites is pivotal for improving rate performance and this approach effectively modifies graphene-based nanomaterials for use as potential anode materials.

The rational design of anode electrodes for sodium-ion batteries faces challenges such as sluggish Na+ diffusion and significant volume expansion. Considerable efforts have been made, including the creation of carbon composites and innovative nanostructures, to advance anode materials. In this study, we synthesized an ultra-small few-layer MoS2 nanostructure confined within a hierarchical porous carbon fiber composite using a nanocasting technique with a novel carbon fiber template. As an anode material, this composite exhibits excellent electrochemical performance in sodium-ion batteries, achieving high reversible capacities of 491 mA h g-1 after 50 cycles at 0.1 A g-1, impressive rate performance of 387 mA h g-1 at 2 A g-1, and superior long-term cycling stability with 234 mA h g-1 at 1 A g-1 after 3000 cycles. Notably, it shows some of the best long-term cycling properties for MoS2-based anode materials in sodium-ion batteries reported to date. This regulatory strategy could provide new insights into fabricating high-performance anode materials for sodium-ion batteries.

Sodium ion batteries (SIBs) are gaining significant interest owing to their potential in grid-scale power management and the affordability of sodium. Iron oxides (FeOx) are viewed as promising anode candidates because of their high theoretical capacity and economical nature. However, FeOx anodes face challenges such as slow reaction kinetics and substantial lattice changes, which result in poor rate performance and rapid capacity loss during the sodiation/desodiation cycles. This study introduces Mn ions into the interstitial sites of the Fe3O4 lattice, creating Mn-incorporated Fe3O4/graphene (M-Fe3O4/G) composites via a straightforward hydrothermal approach. XRD Rietveld refinement and first principle calculations confirm that Mn integration into the structure enhances electron density around the Fermi level, increasing electrical conductivity and enhancing electrochemical properties. Consequently, the M0.1Fe2.9O4/G composite achieves a high reversible capacity of 439.8 mAh g-1 at 100 mA g-1 over 200 cycles. Even under a high current density of 1 A g-1, M-Fe3O4/G composites maintain stability for over 1200 cycles, offering a capacity of 210 mAh g-1. When paired with a Na3V2(PO4)3-type cathode, the Mn-incorporated Fe3O4/G composites exhibit excellent performance in full SIBs, achieving 161.2 mAh g-1 at a current density of 1 A g-1 after 100 cycles. Modulating Mn ions in the Fe3O4 lattice offers valuable insights for optimizing metal oxide anode candidates for SIB applications.

Sodium ion (Na-ion) batteries, known for their affordability and scalability, are a promising substitute for today's lithium-ion batteries. To address the limitation of energy density, one effective solution is to develop a high-voltage anode-free system, utilizing a lightweight aluminum current collector at the anode and a high-voltage sodiumized cathode. This approach, however, demands strict requirements for Na reversibility and electrolyte stability under high voltage. In response, we have strategically designed a 3A zeolite molecular sieve film and constructed a highly aggregated solvation structure based on size effects. This innovation effectively prevents minor yet continuous oxidative decomposition and enhances oxidative stability to 4.5 V, without compromising the anode's Na reversibility (99.91%). Consequently, we achieve anode-free cells with high energy densities of 369 and 372 W h kg-1 for cells operating at 4.0 and 4.25 V, respectively. Additionally, this method supports a long cycle life (250 cycles) for 4.0 V-class anode-free cells, along with a significant cost reduction in a sustainable manner.

Antimony-based materials are considered promising anodes for sodium ion batteries due to their high theoretical capacities and suitable sodium insertion potentials. However, the energy density and cycling stability of reported Sb-based anodes for SIBs have been limited and require significant enhancement. In this study, we present a novel Sb/C hybrid structure where Sb nanorods are encapsulated within a highly conductive nitrogen and sulfur codoped carbon framework (Sb@(N, S-C)). As an anode, this Sb@(N, S-C) hybrid delivers high reversible capacities of 621.1 mAh g^-1 at 100 mA g^-1 after 150 cycles, and 390.8 mAh g^-1 at 1 A g^-1 after 1000 cycles. Even at elevated current densities of 2, 5, and 10 A g^-1, the hybrid demonstrates high reversible capacities of 534.4, 430.8, and 374.7 mAh g^-1, respectively. These outstanding sodium storage capabilities can be credited to the unique cross-linked carbon network, which provides a highly conductive framework that facilitates rapid ion and electron transfer, mitigates volume expansion, and prevents the agglomeration of Sb nanorods during cycling.

Introducing oxygen vacancies in anatase TiO2 has been explored as a promising approach to enhance electron and Na+ ion transport, crucial for achieving excellent electrochemical properties in anatase TiO2. However, deliberately incorporating oxygen vacancies into anatase TiO2 for sodium-ion anodes through a simple and effective method remains challenging. This study presents an innovative technique to integrate oxygen vacancies into urchin-like N-doped carbon-coated anatase TiO2 (NC-DTO) via straightforward plasma treatment. The combination of oxygen vacancies and conductive N-doped carbon coating significantly enhances the sodium storage performance of the NC-DTO. As an anode for sodium-ion batteries, the NC-DTO electrode exhibits outstanding electrochemical performance, achieving a capacity of 272 mA h g-1 at 0.25 C, 98.8% capacity retention after 5000 cycles at 10 C, and an ultrahigh capacity of 150 mA h g-1 at 15 C. Density functional theory calculations, along with experimental results, indicate that the markedly improved sodium storage capacity of NC-DTO arises from increased electronic conductivity due to the N-doped carbon layer, along with a narrowed band gap and reduced sodiation energy barrier from introduced oxygen vacancies. This study underscores that plasma-induced oxygen vacancies in TiO2 offer a promising method to boost the electrochemical properties of TiO2, which can also be extended to other metal oxides for energy storage applications.

Black phosphorus (BP) has gained significant attention from researchers as a potential anode material for sodium-ion batteries (SIB) due to its high theoretical capacity of 2596 mAh g-1 and excellent electrical conductivity of approximately 300 S m-1. Nevertheless, its practical application is hindered by considerable volume changes during electrochemical cycling. In this study, the reversible performance of BP in SIB is greatly improved by covalently linking functionalized BP onto graphene. This enhanced interaction between chemically functionalized BP and graphene contributes to the stability of BP during extended cycling. The bridging technique decreases surface energy and increases the BP thickness, thereby widening the channel between BP nanosheet and graphene. This expanded channel accommodates more sodium ions, leading to better cycling performance. Notably, for the first time, two types of phosphorus-carbon bonds have been identified through experimental analysis. Thanks to this approach, the BP-based SIB anode delivers a specific capacity of 1472 mAh g-1 at 0.1 A g-1 in the 50th cycle and 650 mAh g-1 at 1 A g-1 after 200 cycles.

Symmetric sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) hold promise for large-scale energy storage due to their easy manufacturing process and the plentiful availability of sodium. Despite their potential, many symmetric SIBs face challenges with low energy density. In this study, a superior Na4V2(PO4)3 anode is created through electrochemical preintercalation, leading to the development of a high energy density symmetric SIB. This battery uses Na3V2(PO4)3 as the cathode and Na4V2(PO4)3 as the anode, leveraging the enhanced redox couple of V4+/V2+ for the first time. Both electrodes demonstrate stable electrochemical performance over more than 3000 cycles when tested in a half cell. The resultant symmetric SIBs deliver an output voltage of 3.0 V and achieve an energy density of 138 Wh kg⁻¹ at the cell level. Moreover, the sodium storage mechanism is elucidated under a broadened measurement range of 0.01-3.9 V using in situ X-ray diffraction.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are emerging as viable alternatives to lithium-ion batteries for large-scale energy storage due to the plentiful availability of sodium. Metal sulfides are considered promising anode materials for SIBs because of their affordability and environmental compatibility. In this study, copper sulfides (Cu2S, Cu7S4, and Cu7KS4) are synthesized in a controlled manner for the first time through a simple electrochemical method using KCl-NaCl-Na2S molten salts. The fabricated Cu2S, characterized by its micron-sized flake structure, is evaluated as an anode for SIBs, achieving a capacity of 430 mAh g-1 with an initial Coulombic efficiency of 84.9% at a current density of 100 mA g-1. The Cu2S anode also exhibits excellent capability (337 mAh g-1 at 20 A g-1, equivalent to 50 C) and exceptional long-term cycling performance, maintaining 88.2% of its capacity after 5000 cycles at 5 A g-1, which corresponds to a fade rate of 0.0024% per cycle. Additionally, the pseudocapacitance contribution and the durable porous structure that forms in situ during cycling confer on Cu2S anodes a remarkable rate capability and improved cycling performance, as demonstrated by kinetics analysis and ex situ characterization.

Sodium-ion batteries are a promising solution for large-scale energy storage applications due to the abundant availability of sodium and the low cost of sodium-based materials. As an anode material, phosphorus (P) offers a theoretical capacity of 2596 mAh/g, making it highly suitable for such applications. While red phosphorus (RP) suffers from poor electronic conductivity and lower initial Coulombic efficiency compared to black phosphorus (BP), the development of BP anodes is hindered by high costs and limited production capabilities. To overcome these limitations, we have devised a straightforward and scalable approach to synthesize a layered BP/graphene composite (BP/rGO) through room temperature pressurization. Using this approach, a carbon-black-free and binder-free BP/rGO anode was produced, demonstrating specific charge capacities of 1460.1, 1401.2, 1377.6, 1339.7, 1277.8, 1123.78, and 720.8 mAh/g at current densities of 0.1, 0.5, 1, 5, 10, 20, and 40 A/g, respectively, in rate capability tests. In cycling performance tests, the BP/rGO anode maintained capacities of 1250 and 640 mAh/g at 1 and 40 A/g, respectively, after 500 deep cycles, highlighting a notable advancement in sodium-ion battery anode technology.

A symmetric sodium-ion battery utilizing an aqueous electrolyte has been developed, featuring the NASICON-structured Na3MnTi(PO4)3 as both the anode and cathode. This structure contains two electrochemically active transition metals, facilitating redox reactions with Ti(4+)/Ti(3+) at the anode and Mn(3+)/Mn(2+) at the cathode. The battery based on this bipolar electrode demonstrates a clear voltage plateau around 1.4 V in an aqueous electrolyte, offering stable cycling performance and excellent rate capability. This innovative aqueous symmetric sodium-ion battery combines high safety with low cost and could serve as a solution for large-scale stationary energy storage.

Electrodes capable of higher Na+ storage and enhanced cycling stability are essential for boosting the energy density and rate capability of sodium ion batteries (SIBs). In this study, we introduce a coral-like FeP composite with FeP nanoparticles anchored on a nitrogen-doped three-dimensional carbon framework, referred to as FeP@NC. Thanks to the continuous N-doped carbon framework and a spring-buffering graphitized carbon layer surrounding the FeP nanoparticles, the sodium ion battery using FeP@NC demonstrates ultra-stable cycling performance, maintaining 82.0% capacity retention over 10,000 cycles at a current density of 10 A g^-1. Notably, a unique particle refinement process increasing capacity during cycling has been verified. Specifically, during the first cycle, the FeP nanoparticles undergo a refinement-recombination process, followed by a pronounced global refinement tendency after several cycles. This leads to an increased degree of graphitization and interface magnetization, offering additional active sites for Na+ storage and enhancing capacity progressively with cycling. This capacity enhancement phenomenon is also applicable to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs). This paper provides new insights into the mechanism of capacity improvement during cycling and suggests a viable approach to designing high-performance anode materials for SIBs and LIBs.

The development of hard carbon with a high initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE) and excellent cycling stability is crucial for the effective use of sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). However, defects and oxygen-containing groups that form along the edges or layers of hard carbon are unavoidable and create numerous irreversible Na+ sites, reducing efficiency and potentially causing battery failure. Therefore, eliminating these defect structures is key to improving battery performance. In this study, we present a method of coating free-standing hard-carbon electrodes with soft carbon, significantly reducing the formation of defects and oxygen-containing groups. Electrochemical testing shows that these soft-carbon-coated electrodes achieve an exceptionally high ICE of 94.1% and maintain long-term cycling stability, with 99% capacity retention after 100 cycles at a current density of 20 mA g-1, indicating significant potential for practical sodium storage. The sodium storage mechanism was examined using operando Raman spectroscopy, leading to an extension of the "adsorption-intercalation-pore filling-deposition" model. We propose that the pore filling during the plateau stage occurs in two steps: (1) sodium initially fills pores near the inner wall of the carbon layer, and (2) as these pores approach saturation, additional sodium can deposit onto existing sodium.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) hold potential for large-scale energy storage due to the plentiful and widespread availability of sodium. While various strategies have been effective for addressing challenges posed by the large ion size at moderate to low current densities, enhancing the fast-charging capabilities of SIBs remains crucial to meet growing energy demands on a larger or grid scale. This paper introduces a core-shell Co2VO4/carbon composite anode designed to address fast-charging challenges in SIBs. The combination of Co2VO4's stable spinel structure, the nanosphere dimensions, and the carbon shell results in improved Na+ ion diffusion, increased electron transfer rates, and excellent electrochemical performance. At a very high current density of 5 A g-1, the Co2VO4@C anode demonstrated a capacity of 135.1 mAh g-1 and maintained over 98% capacity retention after 2000 cycles, primarily through a pseudocapacitive process. This research offers insights into fast-charging material development for SIBs and other systems like lithium-ion batteries.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are anticipated to be a viable commercial substitute for lithium-ion batteries in grid electricity storage, given their prospective low cost. Currently, developing anode materials for SIBs at room temperature presents significant challenges. Graphite struggles to accommodate the larger sodium ions (Na+) compared to lithium ions (Li+). Hard carbon, with its larger interlayer distance, offers relatively high storage capacity and long cycle life. Unfortunately, its practical application is hampered by low initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE), primarily due to its large surface area and expensive synthesis process. This study introduces a novel coupled carbonization method to produce cost-effective hard carbon by pyrolyzing and carbonizing a mixture of abundant sucrose and phenolic resin. The specific pyrolysis reaction process and optimized conditions reduce the hard carbon's surface area to just 1.54 m² g⁻¹ and achieve a high initial ICE of 87%. Such achievements in Na+ utilization within the cathode are seldom reported. Furthermore, the hard carbon, with a high interlayer distance of 3.95 Å, achieves a high capacity of 319 mAh g⁻¹ and retains 90% of its capacity over 150 cycles. A full cell was constructed with the synthesized hard carbon anode and an air-stable O3-Na0.9[Cu0.22Fe0.30Mn0.48]O2 cathode, achieving a high ICE of 80% and energy density of 256 Wh kganode⁻¹ (versus hard carbon) with reliable cyclic performance. The study confirms that this synthetic strategy is both feasible and extendable, with potential applications for tunable carbon-based materials beyond their promising properties in Na-ion batteries.

Recent advancements in sodium-ion (NIBs) and potassium-ion batteries (KIBs) present opportunities to enhance lithium-ion battery (LIB) technology and expand the battery market.
