The electrodes with 20 wt % sucrose carbon coating showed outstanding cycle retention over 50 cycles (100%) and remarkable rate capability up to 30 C at room temperature. The cell achieved a high discharge capacity of 155 mAh g(composite)(-1) at 0.1 C, 149 mAh g(composite)(-1) at 1 C, and 82.7 mAh g(composite)(-1) at a 10 C rate.

A three-dimensional spider-web architecture composed of Na2Ti3O7 nanotubes is created via a hydrothermal method. This self-similar network structure displays outstanding performance as an anode in a room temperature sodium-ion battery, used independently of any additives such as binders or conducting agents, for the first time.

Though lithium-ion battery (LIB) technology has long dominated, escalating pressure and rising costs of lithium resources demand the swift advancement of alternative energy storage systems. Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have emerged as a cost-effective option due to their similar electrochemical properties, capturing the interest of researchers. However, significant challenges remain, such as lower reversible capacity and reduced lifespan caused by the larger ionic radius of sodium ions. Addressing these issues, enhancement of anode materials has proven effective. This paper summarizes the most recent research on promising anode materials in SIBs and outlines future prospects.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are gaining attention for large-scale energy storage systems, though their power density is often limited by slow Na+ diffusion in the cathode and anode materials. This paper presents a prototype of an ultrahigh power SIB, featuring a high-rate Na3V2(PO4)3 (NVP) cathode, mesocarbon microbeads (MCMB) anode similar to graphite, and a Na+-diglyme electrolyte. The NVP cathode was found to conform to the Ohmic rule for overpotential. The synthesized NVP@C@carbon nanotubes (CNTs) cathode exhibits high electronic conductivity due to the conductive CNT networks, which decreases overpotential and reduces charge transfer resistances, achieving a rate capability of over 1000C. For the MCMB anode, the initial [Na-diglyme]+ co-intercalation step is governed by pseudocapacitive processes, while the expanded graphite layers ensure fast subsequent ion diffusion. The kinetics of (de)intercalation are well-matched between the cathode and anode. The assembled MCMB|1 m NaPF6 in diglyme|NVP@C@CNTs full-cell SIB results in an energy density of 88 Wh kg−1 at a high power density of approximately 10 kW kg−1. Even at an ultrahigh power density of 23 kW kg−1, it achieves an energy density of 58 Wh kg−1. These promising full-cell results are anticipated to advance the development of high-power SIBs for extensive applications in the future.

The interaction of processes at the anode/electrolyte interface crucially affects the performance of sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). These processes, which occur throughout all components of the electrochemical cell, span a wide range of sizes and timescales. Single-scale investigations often provide limited insights as they fail to encompass this complexity. Comprehensive, multiscale research is necessary to unravel these processes. This perspective article introduces various analytical and theoretical methods and describes how their integration offers a fuller understanding of SIB performance over its lifespan, particularly focusing on interfaces of hard carbon anodes. These methods cover different length- and timescales—from micro to nano, and from cell-level to atomic structures—and encompass a range of physical and electrochemical characteristics. Specifically, the paper explores how mass spectrometric, microscopic, spectroscopic, electrochemical, thermodynamic, and physical methods can be utilized to acquire the diverse information needed to understand battery behavior. Moreover, it discusses how these methods can be combined to clarify the multiscale phenomena at the anode interface and foster a holistic understanding of their impact on the overall functioning of sodium-ion batteries.

Creating 3D graphene/metal composites with extremely small metal particles and strong metal–graphene interfaces for energy storage remains a challenging and seldom-reported task. This study presents a straightforward top-down approach to synthesize SnSb-in-plane nanoconfined 3D N-doped porous graphene networks for use as anodes in sodium ion batteries. These networks consist of interconnected empty N-graphene boxes embedded with ultrasmall SnSb nanocrystals. The encapsulation architecture with plane-to-plane contact significantly increases the interface between N-graphene and SnSb nanocrystals, improving electron conductivity and structural integrity while providing additional interfacial sodium storage. This results in enhanced high-rate sodium storage capacity and stability, as confirmed by experimental data and first-principles simulations. Furthermore, this approach offers new avenues for the cost-effective and large-scale production of 3D graphene/metal composites for various energy-related applications.

We present a novel sodium-ion battery composed of a NaFePO(4) cathode paired with a nanocomposite tin-carbon (Sn-C) sodium-alloying anode. The NaFePO(4) cathode is produced through the conversion of a LiFePO(4) cathode to NaFePO(4) directly within the complete cell, using the Sn-C anode and a sodium-ion electrolyte. The findings demonstrate that this distinctive approach can effectively and efficiently transform LiFePO(4) into NaFePO(4) in a sodium-ion battery operating at 3 V. This system achieves a maximum reversible capacity of 150 mAh g(-1), along with high reversibility and excellent rate capability.

Crystalline Covalent Organic Frameworks (COFs) feature ordered nano-channels that, when equipped with redox-active functional groups, can function as anodes in metal ion batteries such as lithium-ion and sodium-ion batteries. Although sodium's greater abundance makes it a more attractive option than lithium, the larger size of sodium ions leads to energetically unfavorable intercalation with commercial graphite anodes used in Li-ion batteries. Furthermore, the slow movement of these ions within electrodes hampers the rapid sodiation of SIBs. To address this, creating an electronic driving force at the electrodes through chemical modification can be a versatile solution. In this study, we introduce SIB anodes based on three isostructural COFs that have similar Highest Occupied Molecular Orbitals (HOMO) energy levels but different Lowest Unoccupied Molecular Orbitals (LUMO) energy levels. This variation in LUMO levels is deliberately achieved by incorporating electron-deficient centers (such as phenyl, tetrazine, and bispyridine-tetrazine) into the COF modules. With a reduction in cell potential, electrons fill the anti-bonding LUMO, making these charged LUMO levels efficient anodes for capturing the otherwise sluggish sodium ions from the electrolyte. Moreover, the inherent porosity of the COF aids in the accommodation and diffusion of Na+ ions. These COF-based cells demonstrate high specific capacity (energy density) and rate performance (fast charging and discharging), a challenging feat given Na+'s larger size relative to Li+. The bispyridine-tetrazine COF, which has the lowest LUMO energy, achieves a specific capacity of 340 mA h g⁻¹ at 1 A g⁻¹ and 128 mA h g⁻¹ at a high current density of 15 A g⁻¹. A mere 24% capacity drop occurs when increasing the current density from 0.1 to 1 A g⁻¹, the smallest reduction observed among leading COF-based Na-ion battery anodes.

Symmetric sodium-ion batteries feature advantages such as low cost, straightforward manufacturing, and easy recycling, making them ideal for large-scale stationary energy storage. In this study, we introduced a symmetric sodium-ion battery utilizing dual-electron reactions in the NASICON-structured Na3MnTi(PO4)3 material. This Na3MnTi(PO4)3 electrode achieves a stable capacity up to 160 mAh g-1 with a Coulombic efficiency of 97% at 0.1 C, through the redox reactions of Ti3+/4+, Mn2+/3+, and Mn3+/4+. For the first time, we explored a symmetric sodium-ion full-cell using Na3MnTi(PO4)3 as both the cathode and anode in an organic electrolyte, which shows excellent reversibility and cycling performance with voltage plateaus at approximately 1.4 V and 1.9 V. The full-cell delivers a reversible capacity of 75 mAh g-1 at 0.1 C and an energy density of 52 Wh kg-1. Furthermore, both ex-situ XRD analysis and first-principles calculations were used to examine the sodiation mechanism and structural evolution. This research offers a viable approach for enhancing energy density in symmetric sodium-ion batteries.

To create a high-performing sodium-ion battery (SIB) anode, binary zinc phosphides (ZnP2 and Zn3P2) were produced through an uncomplicated solid-state heat treatment process, and their sodium storage capabilities were assessed. ZnP2 showed superior Na reactivity compared to Zn3P2. Consequently, a carbon-modified ZnP2-based composite (ZnP2-C) was developed for enhanced electrochemical performance. Ex-situ analytical techniques were used to explore the electrochemical reaction mechanism of ZnP2-C during the sodiation/desodiation processes. Throughout sodiation, ZnP2 in the composite was converted into NaZn13 and Na3P phases, indicating a one-step conversion reaction. During desodiation, Zn and P in the NaZn13 and Na3P, respectively, fully reformed into the original ZnP2 phase. Thanks to this one-step conversion/recombination of ZnP2 within the composite throughout cycling, ZnP2-C demonstrated high electrochemical performance with a remarkably reversible capacity of 883 mAh g-1 after 130 cycles without any capacity loss and a rapid C-rate capability of 500 mAh g-1 at 1C and 350 mAh g-1 at 3C.

Aromatic organic compounds hold potential as electrode materials in rechargeable batteries and could propel advancements in anode and cathode materials for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). Despite this, most aromatic organic compounds studied as anode materials for SIBs thus far have faced considerable degradation under rapid charge/discharge conditions and exhibit poor long-term cycling performance. This paper introduces a molecular design concept aimed at enhancing the stability of organic compounds used as battery electrodes. The design of the compound [2.2.2.2]paracyclophane-1,9,17,25-tetraene (PCT) employs local aromaticity to stabilize its neutral state and global aromaticity to stabilize its doubly reduced state. This results in an anode material with exceptionally stable cycling performance and impressive capability under fast charge/discharge conditions, offering a promising new approach for the development of electrode materials for SIBs and other battery types.

Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2), recognized as a 2D-layered compound, is a promising candidate for sodium-ion battery (SIB) anodes because of its appealing theoretical capacity and affordability. The primary issues with MoS2 involve a low rate capability due to slow Na+ intercalation kinetics and poor cycling stability caused by the stacking of MoS2 sheets. This study presents a novel architecture of bundled defect-rich MoS2 (BD-MoS2) made from MoS2 with large vacancies bundled by ultrathin MoO3, created through an easy quenching process. As an anode in a SIB, the BD-MoS2 electrode shows ultrafast charging and discharging owing to the pseudocapacitive-controlled Na+ storage mechanism. Both experimental data and theoretical calculations indicate that Na+ can traverse the MoS2 layer through vacancies, allowing not just diffusion along the layer but also enabling 3D Na+ diffusion with enhanced kinetics. Additionally, the bundling architecture reduces sheet stacking, providing excellent cycling stability with highly reversible capacities of 350 and 272 mAh g-1 at 2 and 5 A g-1 after 1000 cycles.

Hard carbon (HC) is currently the most promising option for sodium-ion battery anode materials. Various properties such as the intensity ratio in the Raman spectrum, the lateral size of the HC crystallite (La), and the interlayer distance (d002) are considered factors influencing anode performance. However, these do not directly reflect the bulk characteristics of the Na+ intercalation reaction, as Raman spectroscopy is highly surface-sensitive, and La and d002 offer only one-dimensional crystalline insights. In this study, it is suggested that the crystallite interlayer area (Ai), determined by La, d002, and stacking height (Lc), influences the Na+ intercalation of different HCs. It was found that diverse wood-derived HCs had a comparable total capacity of about 250 mAh g-1, while the Na+ intercalation capacity (Ci) was directly proportional to Ai, with a correlation coefficient of R2 = 0.94. This evaluation factor, Ai, was also applicable to previous studies and showed a strong correlation with their Ci, suggesting that Ai is more broadly applicable than the traditional evaluation methods.

The use of a polyacrylic acid (PAA)-carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC) binder has been shown to improve the performance of oxide-based anodes in batteries. This approach has resulted in the production of oxide powders with exceptionally high capacity and cycling ability, a feat rarely accomplished previously, notably achieved mostly without resorting to specific carbon modifications or morphology control.

Sodium's global abundance makes sodium-ion rechargeable batteries an attractive alternative to lithium-ion batteries for large-scale energy storage, provided there is a cathode material for sodium that offers the required capacity, voltage, and cycle life at a specified charge/discharge rate. Low-cost hexacyanometallates are promising candidates due to their simple synthesis and rigid open framework, which facilitates rapid Na(+) insertion and extraction. In this study, we present a notable effect of interstitial water on the structure and electrochemical behavior of sodium manganese(II) hexacyanoferrates(II) with the nominal formula Na2MnFe(CN)6·zH2O (Na2-δMnHFC). The newly discovered dehydrated Na2-δMnHFC phase demonstrates exceptional electrochemical performance compared to previously reported sodium-ion cathodes. It achieves a reversible capacity of 150 mAh g(-1) in a sodium half-cell and 140 mAh g(-1) in a full cell with a hard-carbon anode at 3.5 V. At a charge/discharge rate of 20 C, the half-cell capacity reaches 120 mAh g(-1), and the cell retains 75% of its capacity after 500 cycles at 0.7 C.

Graphene-based nanomaterials have emerged as promising candidates for anode materials in sodium-ion batteries, owing to graphene's unique properties and the synergistic effects with active materials. Despite this, the 2D structure of graphene permits rapid sodium ion diffusion only in the parallel plane, restricting the rate capability due to poor vertical ion transport. To address this, pore-forming engineering has been used to perforate graphene and simultaneously facilitate the in situ growth of Co3Se4 nanoparticles. The in-plane nanoholes disrupt the graphene’s physical barriers, allowing for rapid longitudinal ion diffusion. This approach also prevents Co3Se4 nanoparticle aggregation because of their strong affinity for graphene. The impressive conductivity and ion transport afforded by this innovative structure enable the Co3Se4/holey graphene composite to demonstrate a significant rate performance of 519.5 mAh g−1 at 5.0 A g−1, along with robust cycle stability. This study concludes that enhancing sodium transport within graphene-based composites is crucial for improving rate performance, and this method effectively modifies graphene-based nanomaterials for potential use as anode materials.

Creating efficient anode electrodes for sodium-ion batteries is challenging, primarily due to the slow diffusion kinetics of Na+ and significant volume expansion. Efforts have been concentrated on developing carbon composites and innovative nanostructures to improve anode materials. In this study, an ultra-small, few-layer MoS2 nanostructure integrated onto a hierarchical porous carbon fiber composite was produced using a nanocasting process with a novel hierarchical porous carbon fiber template. As an anode material, this composite demonstrates exceptional electrochemical performance for sodium-ion batteries, with high reversible capacities of 491 mA h g-1 after 50 cycles at 0.1 A g-1, excellent rate performance of 387 mA h g-1 at 2 A g-1, and remarkable long-term cycling stability, maintaining 234 mA h g-1 at 1 A g-1 after 3000 cycles. It notably exhibits one of the best long-term cycling performances reported for MoS2-based anode materials in sodium-ion batteries, and this strategic approach could provide new perspectives on fabricating high-performance anode materials for these batteries.

Sodium ion batteries (SIBs) are garnering significant interest due to their potential for grid-scale energy management and the affordability of sodium. Iron oxides (FeOx) have emerged as a strong anode candidate, attributed to their high theoretical capacity and low cost. However, FeOx anodes face challenges, including slow reaction kinetics and considerable lattice changes, leading to poor rate performance and rapid capacity loss during sodiation and desodiation. This research introduces Mn ions into the interstitial sites of the Fe3O4 lattice, forming Mn-incorporated Fe3O4/graphene (M-Fe3O4/G) composites via a simple hydrothermal technique. XRD Rietveld refinement and first principle calculations confirm that Mn integration in the lattice structure effectively increases electron density around the Fermi level, resulting in enhanced electrical conductivity and electrochemical performance. The M0.1Fe2.9O4/G composite showcases a notable reversible capacity of 439.8 mAh g-1 at a current density of 100 mA g-1 across 200 cycles. Even at a higher current density of 1 A g-1, the M-Fe3O4/G composites exhibit stability over 1200 cycles, maintaining a capacity of 210 mAh g-1. When paired with a Na3V2(PO4)3-type cathode, the Mn-incorporated Fe3O4/G composites perform effectively in full SIBs, achieving 161.2 mAh g-1 at a current density of 1 A g-1 after 100 cycles. This Mn ion regulation in the Fe3O4 lattice offers valuable insights for enhancing metal oxide anode candidates for SIB applications.

Sodium-ion (Na-ion) batteries, which are cost-effective and scalable, present a promising alternative to current lithium-ion batteries. To address the challenge of lower energy density, the development of a high-voltage anode-free configuration is proposed. This involves using a lightweight aluminum current collector at the anode and a high-voltage sodiumized cathode. Nevertheless, this approach demands strict Na reversibility and high-voltage stability from the electrolyte. In response, a 3A zeolite molecular sieve film has been meticulously designed, and a highly aggregated solvation structure is achieved through size effects. This successfully mitigates trace but ongoing oxidative decomposition, enhancing the oxidative stability to 4.5 V while maintaining the anode's Na reversibility at 99.91%. Consequently, we achieve anode-free cells with high energy densities of 369 and 372 W h kg-1 for 4.0 and 4.25 V class cells, respectively. Additionally, this strategy supports a prolonged lifespan of 250 cycles for 4.0 V-class anode-free cells and significantly lowers costs in an environmentally friendly manner.

Antimony-based (Sb) materials have emerged as promising anode candidates for sodium ion batteries (SIBs) due to their high theoretical capacities and suitable sodium inserting potentials. However, the energy density and cycling stability reported for these Sb-based anodes remain restricted and require substantial enhancement. In this study, we introduce an innovative Sb/C hybrid, where Sb nanorods are encapsulated within highly conductive nitrogen and sulfur codoped carbon (Sb@(N, S-C)) frameworks. As an SIB anode, the Sb@(N, S-C) hybrid demonstrates high reversible capacities of 621.1 mAh g-1 at 100 mA g-1 over 150 cycles, and 390.8 mAh g-1 at 1 A g-1 across 1000 cycles. Even at elevated current densities of 2, 5, and 10 A g-1, the Sb@(N, S-C) hybrid maintains high reversible capacities of 534.4, 430.8, and 374.7 mAh g-1, respectively. These impressive sodium storage capabilities are primarily due to the unique interconnected carbon networks that facilitate fast ion and electron transfer, mitigate volume expansion, and prevent Sb nanorod agglomeration during cycling.

Introducing oxygen vacancies into anatase TiO2 has shown potential for enhancing electron and Na+ ion transport, which is crucial for the material's excellent electrochemical properties. However, achieving this through a simple and efficient method remains challenging for sodium-ion anodes. This study presents an innovative approach to incorporate oxygen vacancies into urchin-like N-doped carbon-coated anatase TiO2 (NC-DTO) using a straightforward plasma treatment. The combination of oxygen vacancies and conductive N-doped carbon coating significantly enhances the sodium storage performance of NC-DTO. As an anode in sodium-ion batteries, the NC-DTO electrode demonstrates outstanding electrochemical performance with a capacity of 272 mA h g^-1 at 0.25 C, 98.8% capacity retention after 5000 cycles at 10 C, and an ultra-high capacity of 150 mA h g^-1 at 15 C. Density functional theory calculations and experimental data indicate that the improved sodium storage in NC-DTO stems from enhanced electronic conductivity due to the N-doped carbon layer, along with a reduced band gap and decreased sodiation energy barrier from the added oxygen vacancies. This research suggests that plasma-induced oxygen vacancies in TiO2 is a promising technique to boost its electrochemical properties, with potential applications in various metal oxides for energy storage systems.

Researchers have recently shown great interest in black phosphorus (BP) as a potential anode material for sodium-ion batteries (SIB) due to its high theoretical capacity of 2596 mAh g-1 and excellent electrical conductivity of approximately 300 S m-1. Despite this, its large volume changes during electrochemical cycling pose a challenge for practical use. In this study, the reversible performance of BP in SIBs is considerably improved by covalently bonding BP to graphene. This chemical functionalization enhances the interaction between BP and graphene, thereby increasing the stability of BP during extended cycling. The bridging approach lowers surface energy and adds thickness to the BP that helps expand the channel between BP nanosheets and graphene. This expansion allows for more sodium ion storage, which enhances cycling performance. Notably, two types of phosphorus-carbon bonds were identified for the first time during experimental analysis. With this approach, the BP-based SIB anode achieves a specific capacity of 1472 mAh g-1 at 0.1 A g-1 in the 50th cycle and 650 mAh g-1 at 1 A g-1 after 200 cycles.

Symmetric sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) hold promise for large-scale energy storage due to their straightforward production and the plentiful availability of sodium resources. Nevertheless, these batteries often exhibit limited energy density. In this study, a superior Na4V2(PO4)3 anode is developed through electrochemical preintercalation. Utilizing Na3V2(PO4)3 as the cathode and Na4V2(PO4)3 as the anode, a high energy density symmetric SIB is constructed for the first time, featuring a deepened V4+/V2+ redox couple. Both electrodes, when evaluated in half cells, demonstrate stable electrochemical performance over 3000 cycles. The symmetric SIB delivers an output voltage of 3.0 V and a cell-level energy density of 138 W h kg-1. Additionally, the sodium storage mechanism is explored using an in situ X-ray diffraction technique across an extended measurement range of 0.01-3.9 V.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) present a promising alternative to lithium-ion batteries for extensive energy storage due to the plentiful availability of sodium. Metal sulfides are considered suitable anode materials for SIBs because of their affordability and environmental friendliness. In this study, for the first time, a series of copper sulfides, specifically Cu2S, Cu7S4, and Cu7KS4, are synthesized in a controlled manner using a straightforward electrochemical method in KCl-NaCl-Na2S molten salts. The prepared Cu2S, featuring a micron-sized flake structure, is evaluated as an anode material for SIBs. It achieves a capacity of 430 mAh g-1 with an initial Coulombic efficiency of 84.9% at a current density of 100 mA g-1. Additionally, the Cu2S anode exhibits exceptional performance with a capacity of 337 mAh g-1 at 20 A g-1 (equivalent to 50 C) and prolonged cycle life, retaining 88.2% of its capacity after 5000 cycles at 5 A g-1 (equating to a fade rate of 0.0024% per cycle). The outstanding rate capability and improved cyclic performance of the Cu2S anodes are attributed to the pseudocapacitance contribution and the robust porous structure developed in situ during cycling, as demonstrated through kinetics analysis and ex situ characterization.

Sodium-ion batteries are appealing for large-scale energy storage due to sodium's abundance and the low cost of sodium compounds. Phosphorus (P) stands out as a potential anode material with a theoretical capacity of 2596 mAh/g. However, red phosphorus (RP) has poor electronic conductivity and lower initial Coulombic efficiency compared to black phosphorus (BP), whose development is hindered by high costs and limited production. To overcome these obstacles, we created a straightforward, scalable approach to synthesize a layered BP/graphene composite (BP/rGO) through room temperature pressurization. Utilizing this method, a carbon-black-free and binder-free BP/rGO anode achieved specific charge capacities of 1460.1, 1401.2, 1377.6, 1339.7, 1277.8, 1123.78, and 720.8 mAh/g at current densities of 0.1, 0.5, 1, 5, 10, 20, and 40 A/g, respectively, during a rate capability test. Additionally, in a cycling performance evaluation, the BP/rGO anodes maintained capacities of 1250 and 640 mAh/g after 500 deep cycles at 1 and 40 A/g, respectively, demonstrating notable advancement in sodium-ion battery anode performance.

A symmetric sodium-ion battery incorporating an aqueous electrolyte has been demonstrated using NASICON-structured Na3MnTi(PO4)3 as both the anode and the cathode. This material's structure includes two electrochemically active transition metals, utilizing the Ti(4+)/Ti(3+) redox couple on the anode and the Mn(3+)/Mn(2+) redox couple on the cathode. The symmetric cell constructed from this bipolar electrode material shows a distinct voltage plateau around 1.4 V when used with an aqueous electrolyte, offering stable cycling performance and excellent rate capability. The development of this aqueous symmetric sodium-ion battery, which emphasizes high safety and low cost, could offer a viable solution for extensive stationary energy storage applications.

Electrodes that can store more Na+ and maintain cycling stability are essential for enhancing both the energy density and rate capability of sodium ion batteries (SIBs). In this study, we introduce a coral-like FeP composite where FeP nanoparticles are anchored and dispersed within a nitrogen-doped three-dimensional carbon framework (FeP@NC). Owing to its highly continuous N-doped carbon structure and a spring-buffering graphitized carbon layer surrounding the FeP nanoparticles, the sodium ion battery made with the FeP@NC composite demonstrates ultra-stable cycling performance at 10 A g^-1, maintaining a capacity retention of 82.0% over 10,000 cycles. Notably, a particle refinement process leading to capacity enhancement during cycling is well verified. Specifically, during the initial cycle, the FeP nanoparticles undergo a refining-recombination process, followed by a general refinement trend after several cycles. This process increases the degree of graphitization and interface magnetization, which creates additional active sites for Na+ storage, thereby contributing to a rising capacity as cycling progresses. This capacity improvement phenomenon is also applicable to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs). This paper offers new insights into the mechanism of enhanced capacity during cycling and provides a viable solution for designing high-performance anode materials for SIBs and LIBs.

Creating hard carbon with a high initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE) and excellent cycling stability is crucial for effective sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). Although, the presence of defects and oxygen-containing groups along carbon edges or layers is unavoidable in hard carbon, leading to numerous irreversible Na+ sites that reduce efficiency and potentially cause battery failure. Thus, removing these unwanted defect structures is crucial to improve battery performance. In this study, we introduce a method involving a soft-carbon coating applied to free-standing hard-carbon electrodes, significantly reducing defects and oxygen-containing groups in hard carbon. Electrochemical testing reveals these electrodes achieve an exceptionally high ICE of 94.1% and excellent cycling durability (99% capacity retention after 100 cycles at a current density of 20 mA g-1), indicating strong practicality for sodium storage applications. The sodium storage mechanism was explored using operando Raman spectroscopy. Our proposed mechanism builds on the "adsorption-intercalation-pore filling-deposition" model, suggesting the pore filling phase in the plateau region can be divided into two steps: (1) sodium initially fills the pores adjacent to the carbon layer’s inner wall, and (2) upon nearing saturation in those pores, additional sodium begins to deposit onto the existing sodium.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) hold great potential for large-scale energy storage systems because sodium is both abundant and widely available. While various approaches effectively address issues related to the large ion size of sodium at mid-to-low current densities, there is still a strong need to improve the fast-charging capabilities of SIBs to meet growing energy demands from large infrastructure to grid scale. This study introduces a core-shell Co2VO4/carbon composite anode aimed at solving the fast-charging issue in SIBs. The combination of the stable spinel structure of Co2VO4, the nanoscale sphere size, and the carbon shell synergistically enhances Na+ ion diffusion, electron transfer rates, and overall electrochemical performance. At an ultrahigh current density of 5 A g-1, the Co2VO4@C anode delivers a capacity of 135.1 mAh g-1 while maintaining over 98% capacity retention after 2000 cycles, via a process dominated by pseudocapacitance. This work offers valuable insights into the design of materials for fast-charging SIBs and could also benefit other battery technologies such as lithium-ion batteries.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are anticipated to be a viable commercial alternative to lithium-ion batteries for grid electricity storage due to their potential for reduced costs in the near future. However, developing suitable anode materials remains a significant hurdle for SIB application, especially at room temperature. Graphite struggles to accommodate the larger sodium ions (Na+) compared to lithium ions (Li+), while hard carbon, with its larger interlayer distance, offers comparatively high storage capacity and long cycle life. Unfortunately, issues such as low initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE) caused by a large surface area and expensive synthesis methods limit its practical usage. In response, we introduce a novel coupled carbonization strategy to create an economical hard carbon material by pyrolyzing and carbonizing a mixture of sucrose and phenolic resin. By leveraging a detailed study of specific pyrolysis reactions and optimal conditions, the resulting hard carbon exhibits an exceptionally low surface area of 1.54 m² g⁻¹ and a high ICE of 87%, rarely reported before, which enhances Na+ utilization efficiency in the cathode. Significantly, the hard carbon, with an interlayer distance of 3.95 Å, achieves a higher capacity of 319 mAh g⁻¹ and sustains a robust capacity retention of 90% over 150 cycles. Additionally, we present a full cell using the prepared hard carbon anode against an air-stable O3-Na0.9[Cu0.22Fe0.30Mn0.48]O2 cathode, achieving a high ICE of 80% and energy density of 256 Wh kganode⁻¹ (vs hard carbon) with consistent cycling performance. These findings underscore the feasibility and adaptability of our synthetic approach, suggesting that these tunable carbon-based materials could find broader applications beyond their promising properties in Na-ion batteries.

Emerging sodium-ion batteries (NIBs) and potassium-ion batteries (KIBs) have potential to complement lithium-ion battery (LIB) technology and broaden the battery market. Hard carbon is seen as a viable anode option for LIBs, NIBs, and KIBs, thanks to its high capacity, sustainability, availability, and stable physicochemical characteristics. In this study, various hard carbons were synthesized via hydrothermal carbonization followed by pyrolysis at different temperatures to precisely adjust their structural properties. When evaluated as anodes, these hard carbons show different ion-storage behaviors for Li, Na, and K, with NIBs reaching the highest reversible capacity. Comprehensive material and electrochemical analyses were conducted to examine how structural features correlate with electrochemical performance and to elucidate the specific mechanisms of alkali-ion storage in hard carbons. Moreover, the top-performing hard carbon was paired with a sodium cathode, Na3V2(PO4)3, in a Na-ion pouch cell, achieving a high power density of 2172 W kg−1 at an energy density of 181.5 Wh kg−1 (considering the total weight of active materials in both anode and cathode). This Na-ion pouch cell also exhibited stable ultralong-term cycling (9000 hours or 5142 cycles), highlighting the significant potential of these materials as sustainable, scalable anodes for advanced Li-battery alternatives.

Sodium ion batteries (NIB, NAB, SIB) are gaining attention as a potentially cost-effective alternative to lithium ion batteries (LIB), due to abundant and evenly distributed sodium resources. Tin is identified as a promising anode material in SIBs, capable of alloying with up to 3.75 Na to store a charge of 847 mAh g(-1). This Account reviews the latest understanding of sodiation-induced phase transformations and their impact on performance across various Sn-based systems, including metallic Sn, its alloys, tin oxide (SnO2), tin sulfide (SnS2/SnS), and tin phosphide (Sn4P3). We first address the sodiation sequence in metallic Sn, focusing on recent insights into the reactions before reaching the final Na15Sn4 intermetallic. We discuss why the series of equilibrium phase transitions expected from the phase diagram does not occur, and instead, sodiation/desodiation involves a series of metastable crystalline and amorphous structures. Additionally, we review modeling-based insights on how these phase transitions affect the mechanical properties of the alloy, shifting from "Sn-like" to "Na-like" bonding. Next, we examine the sodiation reactions in SnO2, asserting that while extensive experimental research on synthesis and testing of tin oxide-based nanocomposites exists, the precise sodiation sequence is still being clarified. Unlike Sn and its alloys, which approach theoretical capacities early in cycling, SnO2 fails to reach the potential 1398 mAh g(-1) due to incomplete Sn to Na15Sn4 alloying reactions that limit electrode capacity. We highlight findings that show the oxide conversion through an intermediate SnO phase, with its reversibility in a half-cell highly reliant on the terminal anodic voltage. We also discuss the sodiation of tin sulfide and tin phosphide phases, presenting emerging microstructural evidence that might explain why both sulfides and phosphides fall short of their promising theoretical capacities under standard testing. Finally, we compare the capacity performance in cycling and rate for various Sn-based anode materials, suggesting the existence of an optimal microstructural architecture.

To address the large volume change and low electronic conductivity of ilmenite found in rechargeable Na-ion batteries (SIBs), a novel anode composed of tiny ilmenite FeTiO3 nanoparticles embedded within carbon nanotubes (FTO⊂CNTs) has been developed. The FTO⊂CNTs are fabricated by coating metal-organic framework (Fe-MOF) nanorods with a TiO2 shell through sol-gel deposition, followed by solid-state annealing of these core-shell Fe-MOF@TiO2 structures. The resulting FTO⊂CNT electrode offers multiple advantages, including a hollow interior in the nanostructure, fully encased ultrasmall electroactive units, a flexible conductive carbon matrix, and a stable solid electrolyte interface (SEI) of FTO during cycling. These FTO⊂CNT electrodes exhibit excellent cycle stability (358.8 mA h g-1 after 200 cycles at 100 mA g-1) and impressive rate capability (201.8 mA h g-1 at 5000 mA g-1), maintaining a high Coulombic efficiency of approximately 99%. Moreover, when paired with a Na3V2(PO4)3 cathode in full SIBs, the assembled FTO⊂CNT//Na3V2(PO4)3 batteries demonstrate superior rate capability and extended cycle life.

A high-performance graphite-Si composite anode for Li-ion batteries was developed using Si nanoparticles (NPs) attached to graphite microparticles, synthesized with a polymer blend of poly(diallyl dimethyl-ammonium chloride) and poly(sodium 4-styrenesulfonate). This polymer blend ensured a uniform distribution of Si NPs during synthesis and acted as a strong artificial solid-electrolyte interphase, significantly improving the composite electrode's cycle stability and rate performance. The electrode achieved a specific capacity of 450 mA h g(-1), maintained 96% capacity retention at a 10 C-rate, retained 95% after 200 cycles, and exhibited identical expansion behavior to a pristine graphite electrode.

Sodium-ion batteries are a promising prospect for future large-scale energy storage due to the availability and affordability of sodium. The progress and commercialization of sodium-ion batteries are contingent upon employing high-capacity electrode materials. SnO2 is one of the metal oxides with a notable theoretical specific capacity for these batteries. However, its substantial volume expansion and low electrical conductivity prevent it from achieving its theoretical potential. While various nanostructured approaches, such as SnO2 nanocomposites, have been explored, the impact of other cell components like electrolytes and binders on specific capacity and cyclic stability remains unclear. This study examines the combined effects of electrolytes and binders on boosting the performance of SnO2 supported by an intertwined network of reduced graphene oxide and partially open multiwalled carbon nanotube hybrids used as anodes in sodium-ion batteries. Our results indicate that using sodium carboxyl methyl cellulose and ethylene carbonate/diethyl carbonate as the electrolyte solvent yields a high specific capacity of 688 mAh g–1 and satisfactory cyclic stability over 500 cycles. This represents a 56% increase in specific capacity compared to using a poly(vinylidene fluoride) binder and propylene carbonate as the electrolyte solvent. This study enhances the understanding of the cooperative role of electrolytes and binders, contributing to the development of metal-oxide-based electrode materials critical for advancing the commercialization of sodium-ion batteries.

A straightforward one-step thermal pyrolysis method has been devised to create a carbon membrane from a natural leaf. This carbonized leaf membrane features anisotropic surfaces and internal hierarchical porosity, achieving a high specific capacity of 360 mAh/g and an initial Coulombic efficiency of 74.8% when used as a binder-free, current-collector-free anode in rechargeable sodium ion batteries. Additionally, extensive carbon membranes with low contact resistance are produced by easily stacking and carbonizing leaves, presenting an effective approach for large-scale sodium-ion battery production.

Bismuth (Bi), as a two-dimensional material, has a significant interlayer spacing along the c-axis (0.395 nm), offering abundant active sites for sodium ions, which ensures effective sodium ion storage. Nevertheless, its limited electrical conductivity and poor cycling performance hinder its practical use. In this study, a nitrogen-doped carbon-coated Bi microsphere (Bi@NC) was synthesized. Thanks to the distinct Bi crystals and the nitrogen-doped carbon coating, the resulting Bi@NC anode demonstrated impressive cycling stability and excellent rate performance. Furthermore, when the Bi@NC anode was paired with a Na₃V₂(PO₄)₃@C cathode in a full battery, it showed outstanding sodium storage capabilities, maintaining 57 mA h g⁻¹ after 2000 cycles at a current of 1.0 A g⁻¹.

Sodium-ion batteries are increasingly viewed as a cost-effective alternative to lithium-ion technology for large-scale energy storage, but safety remains a significant concern for practical use. This study proposes a safer sodium-ion battery by utilizing a nonflammable phosphate electrolyte, specifically trimethyl phosphate (TMP), in conjunction with a NaNi0.35Mn0.35Fe0.3O2 cathode and an Sb-based alloy anode. The TMP electrolyte's physical and electrochemical compatibilities are assessed through tests such as ignition, ionic conductivity, cyclic voltammetry, and charge-discharge measurements. The findings show that the TMP electrolyte with an FEC additive is entirely nonflammable and operates within a broad electrochemical window (0–4.5 V vs. Na/Na+). Within this range, both the Sb-based anode and the NaNi0.35Mn0.35Fe0.3O2 cathode demonstrate high reversible capacity and cycling stability, comparable to those in carbonate electrolyte. From these results, a nonflammable sodium-ion battery is developed using an Sb anode, a NaNi0.35Mn0.35Fe0.3O2 cathode, and a TMP + 10 vol% FEC electrolyte, which performs effectively with significant capacity and cycling performance, suggesting a promising approach to creating safer sodium-ion batteries suitable for large-scale energy storage.

Structural phase transitions enable modifications to a material's properties without introducing additional elements, offering significant technological benefits. The transformation of hexagonal-SnS2 to orthorhombic-SnS is achieved through annealing in an argon atmosphere, with the resulting SnS exhibiting superior sodium-ion storage performance compared to SnS2, due to its structural merits. This paper introduces a SnS@graphene architecture designed for sodium-ion battery anodes, utilizing two-dimensional SnS and graphene nanosheets as complementary components. The SnS@graphene hybrid nanostructured composite produced demonstrates an exceptional specific capacity of 940 mAh g(-1), along with impressive rate capabilities of 492 and 308 mAh g(-1) after 250 cycles at current densities of 810 and 7290 mA g(-1), respectively. Its performance surpasses that of most known anode materials for Na-ion batteries. Combining ex situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and ex situ X-ray diffraction provides insights into the SnS@graphene formation mechanism and the synergistic Na-storage reactions in the anode. SnS undergoes a two-structural-phase transformation (orthorhombic-SnS → cubic-Sn → orthorhombic-Na3.75Sn), whereas SnS2 experiences a more complex three-phase transformation (hexagonal-SnS2 → tetragonal-Sn → orthorhombic-Na3.75Sn) during sodiation. The minimal structural changes in SnS likely contribute to its robust structural and cycling stability in sodium-ion battery applications. These findings highlight that the SnS@graphene architecture possesses distinct features advantageous for high-performance energy storage solutions.

Sodium-ion batteries are emerging as a promising alternative to lithium-ion batteries, particularly for large-scale energy storage systems. The successful deployment of these batteries is contingent upon the development of novel anode materials, as key anode materials like graphite and silicon, commonly used in lithium-ion batteries, do not perform adequately in sodium-ion systems. We have developed innovative SnS/C nanocomposites using a top-down approach for use as anode materials in sodium-ion batteries. These nanocomposites display significantly enhanced electrochemical performance compared to pure SnS, exhibiting notable improvements in cycling stability and rate capabilities. SnS/C nanocomposites demonstrate outstanding capacity retention across diverse current rates, achieving capacities up to 400 mA h g−1 even at a high current density of 800 mA g−1 (2C). To elucidate the reaction mechanism of these SnS/C nanocomposites, we conducted ex situ transmission electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, and operando X-ray absorption near edge structure analyses.

With the growing demand for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), creating cost-efficient anode materials, such as metal oxides, for Na-ion storage has become a major area of interest. The larger ion radius of Na compared to Li hinders most metal oxide electrodes from reaching the performance levels observed in Li-ion batteries. In this study, iron oxide is used to explore the idea that designing an amorphous structure can improve the Na-ion storage capabilities of metal oxides. We successfully synthesized amorphous Fe2O3/graphene composite nanosheets (Fe2O3@GNS) via a simple process to serve as anodes for SIBs. It was found that amorphous Fe2O3 nanoparticles, averaging 5 nm in diameter, were uniformly attached to the surface of graphene nanosheets through strong C-O-Fe oxygen-bridge bonds. Compared to crystalline Fe2O3, amorphous Fe2O3@GNS exhibited enhanced sodium storage characteristics, such as high electrochemical activity, an initial Coulombic efficiency of 81.2%, and commendable rate performance. At a current density of 100 mA/g, the amorphous Fe2O3@GNS composites achieved a specific capacity of 440 mAh/g, significantly surpassing the 284 mAh/g capacity of crystalline Fe2O3. Even at a high current density of 2 A/g, the amorphous Fe2O3@GNS composites maintained a specific capacity of 219 mAh/g. The superior electrochemical performance can be attributed to the amorphous structure of Fe2O3 and its robust interface interaction with GNS, which accommodate more electrochemically active sites, offer additional transmission paths for sodium ions, enhance electron transfer, and effectively mitigate volume changes of the host materials during sodiation and desodiation. This approach to designing amorphous iron oxide anodes for SIBs is anticipated to also benefit the development of various amorphous nanostructures in other metal oxides, thereby enhancing their Na-ion storage capabilities.

The solid-electrolyte interface (SEI) layer in sodium-ion batteries significantly impacts the batteries' capacity degradation and cycling stability. Yet, research on the SEI film in sodium-ion batteries is limited, and the formation mechanism of the SEI film remains uncertain. This study uses DFT to investigate the reduction mechanisms of ethylene carbonate (EC), propylene carbonate (PC), vinylene carbonate (VC), ethylene sulfite (ES), 1,3-propylene sulfite (PS), and fluorinated ethylene carbonate (FEC). Calculations were performed to determine the reaction activation energies, Gibbs free energies, enthalpies, and transition state structures. The results show that the additives VC, ES, and PS in the electrolyte are more readily reduced by one electron to create organic components in the anode SEI film. The order of preference for one-electron reduction to form organic SEI components is VC>PC>EC, whereas, for two-electron reduction to form the inorganic component Na2 CO3, the preference is EC>PC>VC. Additionally, it is more challenging for ES and PS sulfites to undergo two-electron reduction to form inorganic Na2 SO3 compared to the reduction of carbonate esters. The study also suggests that the one- and two-electron reduction pathways of FEC are more efficient for forming inorganic NaF components.

To advance lithium and sodium ion battery technology, it is crucial to comprehend how the chemical structures influence the properties of various components. Operando structural studies provide valuable insights into battery operation, but isolating the contributions of different battery stack components (such as electrodes, current collectors, electrolyte, and binders) and focusing on specific materials remains challenging. We utilized operando X-ray diffraction computed tomography (XRD-CT) to analyze particular components of a largely unaltered working cell, extracting detailed, space-resolved structural information on both crystalline and amorphous phases during cycling through Rietveld and pair distribution function (PDF) methods. We demonstrate this approach with the first comprehensive structural analysis of sodium cycling in a phosphorus anode, uncovering unexpectedly distinct mechanisms for sodiation and desodiation in this promising, high-capacity anode system.

All-solid-state sodium ion batteries (AS3iBs) are in high demand for stationary energy storage systems due to their enhanced safety and stability across a broad temperature range. Hard carbon (HC), known for its affordable cost, low redox potential, and high capacity, is essential for developing practical large-scale sodium-ion batteries. However, the low initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE) of batteries using this anode material limits their energy density. This study investigates two methods to improve the ICE of pristine HC: i) additional pyrolysis and ii) presodiation via the thermal decomposition of NaBH4. Raman spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and electrochemical experiments demonstrate that thermal treatment boosts the Csp2 content in the HC structure, while presodiation incorporates sodium into the inherent irreversible sites. As a result, presodiated HC achieves an extraordinary ICE (>99%) compared to thermally treated (90%) and pristine HC (83%) in half-cell setups. Furthermore, an AS3iB constructed with presodiated HC as the anode and NaCrO2 as the cathode achieves a substantial ICE of 92% and an initial discharge energy density of 294 Wh/kg_cathode.

Devices with high gravimetric and volumetric energy densities are in great demand due to the swift advancement of electric vehicles, as well as portable and wearable electronics. Electrospinning emerges as a promising technique for creating self-supporting electrodes with these desired properties. Nonetheless, traditional electrospun electrodes face limitations in energy density due to the low active material mass loadings (around 20%-30 wt%). This paper introduces a biomimetic strategy, inspired by sticky spider webs, to develop a high-performance anode that enhances both gravimetric and volumetric energy densities. By electrospinning and subsequent thermal treatment, freestanding carbon nanofiber (CNF) membranes with more than 50 wt% bismuth were created. These membranes form CNF networks tightly integrated with active Bi clusters, offering superior mechanical protection and efficient charge transport pathways, a combination usually challenging to achieve. As a lithium-ion battery anode, the composite membrane exhibits a high reversible capacity of 483 mA h g⁻¹ at 100 mA g⁻¹ after 200 cycles and superior rate performance of 242 mA h g⁻¹ at 1 A g⁻¹. When used in sodium ion batteries, it shows a remarkable reversible specific capacity of 346 mA h g⁻¹ and excellent cycling performance of 186 mA h g⁻¹ at 50 mA g⁻¹ after 100 cycles. This study presents a straightforward, cost-effective, and environmentally friendly approach to produce freestanding, binder-free composite electrodes with high loadings for use in both LIBs and SIBs.

Hard carbon (HC) is a promising candidate for a commercial anode material in lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). Nevertheless, the existing methods for evaluating battery performance rely on...

Two-dimensional molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) has garnered significant attention for a range of applications, including catalysts, energy storage, and electronics. Nevertheless, the absence of effective exfoliation techniques for producing 2D materials on a large scale remains a major technical challenge for practical applications. We present a simple liquid-phase exfoliation method to enhance the exfoliation efficiency of single-layer MoS2 sheets in 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP), facilitated by sodium hydroxide (NaOH). This method significantly increases the concentration of exfoliated MoS2 nanosheets compared to traditional liquid-phase exfoliation methods using NMP. Additionally, we demonstrate the stable operation of sodium-ion batteries using exfoliated MoS2 and MoS2-rGO composite as anode materials.

The potential enhancement of sodium ion batteries (SIBs) performance through the utilization of oxygen vacancies (OVs) has seldom been explored. In this study, using MoO(3-x) nanosheet anodes as a model, we demonstrate for the first time the positive impact of OVs on SIB performance. Furthermore, these advantages under deep-discharge conditions are amplified with the application of an ultrathin Al2O3 coating. Various measurements confirm that OVs enhance electric conductivity and the Na-ion diffusion coefficient, while the ultrathin coating effectively minimizes cycling-induced solid-electrolyte interphase. The coated nanosheets delivered high reversible capacity and excellent rate capability, achieving 283.9 mAh g(-1) at 50 mA g(-1) and 179.3 mAh g(-1) at 1 A g(-1) after 100 cycles. This research not only highlights the potential of OVs in sodium energy storage but also provides new opportunities for developing strategies to exploit defects in other energy storage systems.

Heterostructure engineering is a highly promising approach for enhancing the slow kinetics in sodium ion battery (SIB) anodes. In this study, we conduct a comprehensive analysis of how different heterostructure interfaces of discharging products (Na2O, Na2S, Na2Se) affect rate performance. First-principle calculations demonstrate that the Na2S/Na2Se interface has the lowest sodium diffusion energy barrier (0.39 eV) among the interfaces studied (Na2O/Na2S, Na2O/Na2Se, and Na2S/Na2Se). This is attributed to its minimal interface deformation, similar electronegativity, and comparable lattice constant. Experimental results verify that a metal sulfide/metal selenide (SnS/SnSe2) hierarchical anode achieves excellent rate performance, with its normalized capacity at 10 A g-1 reaching 45.6% of that at 0.1 A g-1. The design strategy proposed in this study aids in creating high-performance anodes for advanced battery systems.

Antimony/carbon (Sb@C) microspheres are synthesized through a simple self-catalyzing solvothermal process, and their suitability as anode materials for sodium-ion batteries is explored. Structural and morphological analyses show that Sb@C microspheres consist of Sb nanoparticles (approximately 20 nm) evenly encapsulated within a carbon matrix. The self-catalyzing solvothermal process is confirmed by comparative experiments with various starting materials. The Sb@C microspheres produced exhibit outstanding sodium storage performance, with a reversible capacity of 640 mAh g(-1), excellent rate performance, and a prolonged cycling stability retaining 92.3% capacity over 300 cycles, indicating their potential as promising anode materials for sodium-ion batteries.

Layered transition metal oxides based on sodium and featuring an O3-type structure hold promise as cathodes for sodium-ion batteries. Nonetheless, rapid capacity fade and poor rate performance due to significant structural changes and interfacial degradation inhibit their application. This research introduces a NaPO3 surface-modified O3-type layered NaNi1/3 Fe1/3 Mn1/3 O2 cathode, which shows enhanced high-voltage stability through a protective layer against acid attack. This protection is achieved by a solid-gas reaction between cathode particles and gaseous P2O5. The NaPO3 nanolayer effectively stabilizes the crystal structure by preventing surface parasitic reactions and boosting the average voltage observed. The surface-modified cathode demonstrates superior cyclic stability (80.1% compared to 63.6%) after 150 cycles at 1 C over a voltage range from 2.0 V to 4.2 V (vs Na+/Na). Additionally, owing to the inherent ionic conductivity of NaPO3, the modified cathode exhibits excellent rate capability (103 mAh g^-1 compared to 60 mAh g^-1) at 10 C. The findings of this study offer a practical approach for advancing high-rate and long-lasting sodium-ion battery technologies.

Incorporating heteroatoms is known to effectively prevent phase transitions in layered sodium-ion battery cathodes, although the behavior of these heteroatoms during operation is not fully understood at the atomic level. This study uses density functional theory calculations alongside experimental observations to investigate the mitigation behavior of Mg dopants and their mechanisms in P2-Na0.67Ni0.33Mn0.67O2 under operational conditions. Upon extracting Na, voids are created that draw some Mg dopants from the transition metal (TM) layers into the Na layers, particularly when there is a high concentration of Mg in the TM layer. This results in the collective diffusion of multiple Mg ions, eventually leading to Mg-enriched regions (Mg segregation) separate from Ni vacancies. This segregation, driven by the void-pump effect, effectively curbs the P2-O2 phase transition, leveraging the stronger Mg-O electrostatic attraction which reinforces the integrity of adjacent oxygen layers and mitigates lattice volume changes during high-voltage cycling, thereby inhibiting crack growth. This research offers essential insights into the behavior of heteroatoms in layered cathodes at the atomic level, paving the way for advancements in energy storage technologies.

Sodium (Na) ion batteries (SIBs) offer affordable energy storage solutions but are currently limited by low energy density. Incorporating oxygen (O) redox into Na-storage cathodes is seen as a promising approach to increase capacity and address the energy density limitation. However, challenges persist in dealing with the irreversible electrochemical behavior that comes with O release. Additionally, the O redox processes and related structural changes are not yet fully understood. This paper explores the O redox mechanism in Na-storage transition metal oxides. It identifies challenges related to reaction irreversibility and structural degradation, drawing on advanced characterization methods. Furthermore, we discuss strategies to potentially enhance the electrochemical performance of O redox and suggest future research directions for developing viable O redox cathode materials.

The P2-type layered oxide Na2/3Ni1/3Mn2/3O2 is a promising material for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), but it encounters a significant P2–O2 phase transition during high-voltage charging, causing substantial volume changes and poor cycling performance. To address this, a Quasi-zero strain cathode, P2-Na0.75Li0.15Mg0.05Ni0.1Mn0.7O2, has been developed, which eliminates the P2–O2 transition and reduces volume change to just 0.49%, resulting in excellent cycling performance with 83.9% capacity retention after 500 cycles at 5 C. This low-volume strain is due to two factors: (1) Mg2+ ions in the Na layer acting as "pillars" to stabilize the crystal structure during sodium removal, thus limiting structural changes at high voltage. (2) Li+ ions entering the transition metal layer help reduce electron localization in the highly desodiated state and effectively fix coordination oxygen atoms, preventing the P2–O2 transition slip. This study not only offers new insights into the synergistic substitution effects of Li and Mg on the structural stability of P2-type cathodes but also presents an effective approach to developing SIB cathode materials with ultra-low bulk strain.

Prussian blue has garnered significant attention as a potential candidate for sodium-ion battery cathodes, owing to its open frameworks and high working potential. Nevertheless, its performance in practical sodium-ion batteries is hindered by the presence of interstitial water in its crystal structure and poor electronic conductivity. In this study, acid-assisted ball milling synthesis was utilized as an effective method to produce surface-modified Prussian blue. Using (CH3COO)2Fe as the starting material, the ball milling synthesis resulted in Prussian blue being modified with carboxyl functional groups on its surface, significantly reducing interstitial water content and enhancing electrochemical cycling performance. Moreover, this synthesis technique endowed the resultant Prussian blue with an increased surface area, thereby improving its electrochemical rate performance. As a sodium-ion battery cathode, the synthesized Prussian blue yielded a specific capacity of 145.3 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C and 113.7 mAh g−1 at 1 C, retaining 54.5% of the initial capacity after 1000 cycles at 1 C (1 C = 170 mA g−1). A solid-state sodium-ion battery was also assembled, employing the prepared Prussian blue as the cathode and Na metal as the anode, achieving a high specific capacity of 128.7 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C. This study provides an effective approach to address the limitations of Prussian blue for its commercial viability.

P2-type layered oxides incorporating Fe and Mn are garnering significant attention for use as cathode materials in sodium ion batteries (SIB) due to their cost-effective metal composition and high specific capacity. Nonetheless, they are prone to rapid capacity degradation and complex phase changes. This study addresses these issues by adjusting the crystal structure and enhancing the electrochemical performance of Na0.67Mn0.5Fe0.5O2 through Al doping at Mn or Fe sites, elucidating Al's role in improving rate capability and cycling stability. (1) Substituting Al for Mn or Fe reduces lattice parameters a and c while increasing the d spacing and Na-O bond length, thereby enhancing Na+ diffusion and rate capability, notably for Na0.67Mn0.5Fe0.47Al0.03O2. (2) Al doping decreases TMO2 thickness and fortifies TM-O/O-O bonding, elevating the stability of the layered structure and capacity retention. (3) Al doping minimizes Mn3+ content and Jahn-Teller distortion, decreasing irreversible phase transitions. (4) Al doping also reduces lattice volume changes and structural strain, further enhancing layered structure stability and cycling performance, particularly when Al substitutes for Fe. The detailed understanding of Al's role may be beneficial for developing high-performance SIB cathodes via strategic lattice doping.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) hold significant promise for large-scale energy storage applications. Among them, P2-type manganese-based layered oxides are particularly noted for their high theoretical capacity, low cost, and environmental friendliness. Despite these advantages, their water sensitivity and limited cycling stability present challenges, with the mechanisms underlying these issues remaining unclear. This study explores copper substitution to mitigate the Jahn-Teller effect of Mn3+ and influence the associated lattice structure. The research thoroughly examines the water sensitivity and charge compensation mechanisms. Findings reveal that water sensitivity is linked to the Na+/vacancy ordering in the Na interlayers, as water molecules more readily intercalate into charged state electrodes, although the propensity for water uptake does not escalate with Na+ extraction. Additionally, Mn2+ develops on the electrode surfaces during the initial discharge, while the bulk redox reactions predominantly involve Mn3+ and Mn4+. The introduction of Cu into the transition metal layer influences the Na+/vacancy arrangement and inhibits Mn2+ formation on the Na0.7Mn0.9Cu0.1O2 electrode, improving air stability and storage capabilities.

In O3-type sodium ion battery (SIB) cathodes, phase transition and changes in lattice parameters typically occur, leading to increased voltage hysteresis and reduced energy efficiency. Considering the cost challenges that hinder the widespread use of SIBs in large-scale energy storage, we focus on Co/Ni-free NaxCu0.18Fe0.3Mn0.52O2 (where x = 0.8, 0.85, 0.9) and suggest a straightforward approach to minimize voltage hysteresis. It was discovered that with a Na content of 0.8, the material achieved the highest energy efficiency of 95.4% after activation (2.5-4.0 V, 50 mA g-1, by the 50th cycle), along with a favorable capacity retention (approximately 0.056% decay per cycle). Further analysis showed that Na0.8Cu0.18Fe0.3Mn0.52O2 undergoes a smooth O3-P3 phase transition and does not exhibit changes in the O3 phase lattice parameters. The critical factor is the presence of an O3/P3 composite in the material. This study provides a simple strategy for the rational design of O3-type cathodes with high energy efficiency and may inspire the search for layered oxides with greater O3/P3 critical Na content through element modification.

Layered O3-type sodium oxides (NaMO2, with M as a transition metal) typically undergo an O3-P3 phase shift at a low redox voltage of around 3 V (vs. Na+ /Na) during sodium extraction and insertion. This results in nearly 50% of their total capacity being confined to this low voltage range, leading to inadequate energy density for sodium-ion battery (NIB) cathodes. Consequently, developing high-voltage O3-type cathodes is challenging because it is difficult to increase the phase-transition voltage through reasonable structural modifications. This paper introduces a novel O3-type sodium insertion material for NIB usage. The engineered O3-type Na0.7 Ni0.35 Sn0.65 O2 material achieves the highest redox potential of 3.7 V (vs. Na+ /Na) among known O3-type materials utilizing the Ni2+/Ni3+ couple, due to its enhanced Ni-O bond ionicity and decreased orbital overlap between transition metals and oxygen in the MO2 layers. This research offers an orbital-level insight into the operating potentials of the nominal redox couples for O3-NaMO2 cathodes. The described strategy may be employed to design electrodes for enhanced performance.

Sodium-ion batteries (SiB) are viewed as a significant alternative to the existing Lithium-ion batteries (LiBs). Despite this potential, SiB technology is still in its infancy and undergoing early-stage development with a broad range...

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) offer a promising solution for developing cost-efficient and safe energy storage systems to meet large-scale storage needs. In this study, we synthesized manganese oxide (α-MnO2) nanorods for potential use in SIBs. We conducted a systematic investigation of the crystal structure, which plays a vital role in achieving high-performance energy storage, focusing on the metal oxide cathode. Using density functional theory (DFT) studies, the intercalation of sodium into the α-MnO2 structure was explored, revealing that Na ions exhibit easy diffusion through the MnO2 lattice with a low diffusion barrier of 0.21 eV. As a cathode material for SIBs, MnO2 demonstrated a moderate capacity of 109 mAh·g–1 at a C/20 current rate and remarkable cycling stability, retaining 58.6% capacity after 800 cycles in a NaPF6/EC+DMC (5% FEC) electrolyte. In a NaClO4/PC (5% FEC) electrolyte, it achieved a significantly higher capacity of 181 mAh·g–1 at the same current rate, though with a rapid capacity decline of 11.5% after 800 cycles. The results indicate that the superior cycling performance, along with efficient charge-discharge characteristics, is attributed to the MnO2's high crystallinity and hierarchical nanorod structure.

Layered manganese-based cathode materials are highly valued for their significant specific capacities in sodium ion batteries. Nevertheless, the Jahn-Teller effect and unavoidable phase transitions hinder their cycling stability and rate performance. In this study, we introduce a P2-type manganese oxide nanoplate cathode material enhanced by Mo-substitution, featuring an oriented stacking structure and exposed {010} active facets. This manganese oxide nanoplate cathode demonstrates an exceptional capacity retention of 87.8% after 1200 cycles at 10C (2000 mA g-1). It presents a specific power density reaching 530 W Kg-1, coupled with a specific discharge capacity of 143.9 mA h g-1 at 1C and 89.6% capacity retention over 100 cycles. The excellent electrochemical performance is attributed to the effective chemical modification and unique structural attributes of the manganese oxide nanoplate. Mo-modification enhances the manganese oxide cathode with increased lattice space and average oxidation state, promoting favorable Na+ diffusion which suppresses the Jahn-Teller effect and boosts structural stability, thus facilitating an extensive cycling lifespan. The multilayer oriented stacking nanoplate structure with exposed {010} active facets further aids in providing additional surface active sites and reducing the Na+ diffusion distance, improving the rate capability.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are emerging as one of the leading candidates to complement lithium-ion batteries and diversify the battery market. Nonetheless, developing cathode materials with high-rate performance and long-cycle stability for SIBs remains a significant challenge. To address this, a method is demonstrated to improve rate and cycling performance by incorporating an ordered bicontinuous porous structure into SIB cathode materials. Prussian blue analogues (PBAs) are chosen due to their promise as SIB cathode materials. The 3D continuous channels in the PBAs facilitate rapid Na+ ion diffusion, and their bicontinuous architecture ensures mechanical stability, resulting in excellent rate capability (80 mAh g−1 at 2.5 A g−1) and an ultralong cycling life exceeding 3000 cycles at 0.5 A g−1. This places them among the top-performing PBA-based cathodes reported. This study paves a new path for enhancing ion diffusion kinetics in rechargeable battery electrodes and offers a paradigm for addressing the problem of electrode failure due to high-stress concentration during ion storage.

In layered oxide cathodes of lithium-ion batteries, cation migration frequently occurs due to the similar ionic radii of lithium and transition metals (TMs). Despite significant differences in ionic radii between sodium and TMs, migration of TMs into the sodium layer still transpires in layered cathodes of sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), causing pronounced electrochemical degradation. To investigate the cause of TM migration in layered SIB cathodes, we examine NaCrO2—a typical layered cathode that experiences substantial TM migration—finding that this migration arises from arbitrary desodiation and the resulting formation of a sodium-free layer at high charging potentials. To combat this problem, we propose a Ru/Ti co-doping strategy. In this approach, the doped active Ru undergoes initial oxidation to facilitate selective desodiation, while the doped inactive Ti acts as a support structure to prevent complete desodiation in TM layers containing Ru. This effectively suppresses the formation of sodium-free layers, thereby enhancing the electrochemical performance.

P2-type Na2/3Ni1/3Mn2/3O2 (NNMO) is a potential cathode material for sodium-ion batteries due to its theoretically high capacity and operating voltage, which can achieve high energy storage density. Nonetheless, it experiences poor cycling stability primarily due to an undesirable phase transition from P2 to O2. To address this, electrochemically active Fe3+ ions are incorporated into the NNMO lattice, resulting in the formation of Na2/3Ni1/3Mn2/3-xFexO2 (x = 0, 1/24, 1/12, 1/8, 1/6) to stabilize the P2-type crystal structure. In these Fe-substituted materials, both the Ni2+/Ni4+ and Fe3+/Fe4+ redox pairs are active, and the P2-O2 phase transition is significantly reduced during cycling, as confirmed through ex situ X-ray diffraction. Consequently, the optimized Na2/3Ni1/3Mn7/12Fe1/12O2 (1/12-NNMF) demonstrates prolonged cycling stability with a fade rate of 0.05% per cycle over 300 cycles at 5 C. Additionally, 1/12-NNMF exhibits excellent rate capabilities (65 mA h g-1 at 25 C) and superior performance at low temperatures (94% capacity retention at -25 °C after 80 cycles) due to enhanced Na diffusion from Fe doping, as inferred from electrode kinetics studies. Furthermore, 1/12-NNMF shows impressive sodium-ion full-cell performance when paired with an LS-Sb@G anode, indicating potential for practical application.
